This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"pages":{"1893493":{"pageid":1893493,"ns":0,"title":"Leahy","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|Canadian folk group originating from Lakefield, Ontario}}\n{{for multi|the surname|Leahy (surname)|other uses|Leahy (disambiguation)}}\n{{Infobox musical artist| <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians -->\n| name            = Leahy \n| image           = Leahy 2005.jpg \n| caption         = Leahy performing in 2005 \n| image_size      = <!-- Only for images smaller than 220 pixels --> \n| landscape       = yes\n| background      = group_or_band\n| origin          = [[Lakefield, Ontario]], Canada\n| genre           = [[Folk music|Folk]]/[[Country music|Country]]/[[Celtic music|Celtic]]\n| years_active    = 1980s&ndash;present |\n| associated_acts = {{plainlist|\n*[[Shania Twain]]\n* [[Natalie MacMaster]]\n}}\n| label           = [[Virgin Records]]\n| website             = [http://www.leahymusic.com/ www.leahymusic.com]\n| current_members = Donnell Leahy<br />Erin Leahy<br />Angus Leahy<br />Maria Leahy<br />Siobheann Donohue<br />Doug Leahy<br />Agnes Enright<br />Frank Leahy |\n| past_members    = Denise Leahy<br />Chrissie Leahy<br />Julie Leahy |\n}}\n\n'''Leahy''' is a [[Canadians|Canadian]] [[folk music]] group. The eight band members, all from the Leahy family of 11 siblings, are from [[Lakefield, Ontario]] and have been touring Canada and internationally since the early 1980s, when they were known as '''The Leahy Family'''. In 1985, they were the subject of a short film entitled ''Leahy: Music Most of All'' which received an [[Academy Awards|Academy Award]] in the category of \"Best Foreign Student Film.\"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oscars.org/awards/saa/winners/winners.pdf |title=Student Film Award Winners -- By Year |publisher=Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences |accessdate=August 22, 2010 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120229173821/http://www.oscars.org/awards/saa/winners/winners.pdf |archivedate=February 29, 2012 }}</ref>\nThe members of Leahy take significant pride in their Irish roots and Canadian upbringing.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://irishamerica.com/2006/10/leahy-staying-true-to-the-tune/ | title=Leahy: Staying True to the Tune | date=October 2006 }}</ref>\n\nThe line-up of the group varies depending upon the availability of its members, who are present or absent due to marriage, childrearing and other obligations. During the 1980s and early 1990s, the band recorded a number of privately released LPs and cassettes (most of which used the same title, ''The Leahy Family'') which were sold at their concerts and they were frequent guests at the [[Big Valley Jamboree]] concerts in [[Saskatchewan]] and [[Alberta]].\n\nIn 1997, the band resumed recording with their \"relaunch\" album, ''[[Leahy (album)|Leahy]]'' which also introduced the group's new branding. ''Leahy'' was an instrumental album, but the band also includes vocal performances in their live performances and subsequent albums have included both vocals and instrumentals.\n\nDespite their established history, they were awarded two [[Juno Awards of 1998|Juno awards in 1998]], for [[Juno Award for New Group of the Year|Best New Group]]<ref name=\"Inc.1998\">{{cite magazine|author=Larry LeBlanc|title=McLaughlin at top of Juno nominations|magazine=Billboard|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GQ8EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA14|date=21 February 1998|publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc.|pages=14\u2013|issn=0006-2510}}</ref> and [[Juno Award for Instrumental Album of the Year|Best Instrumental Artist]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://junoawards.ca/database/artist-summary/?artist_name=leahy |title=(Juno Awards Database Lookup) |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110723180613/http://junoawards.ca/database/artist-summary/?artist_name=leahy |archivedate=2011-07-23 }}</ref>  The following year, Leahy took a third Juno Award, for [[Juno Award for Country Recording of the Year|Best Country Group or Duo]]. Also in 1998, Leahy were added as the opening act for Canadian country singer [[Shania Twain]]'s 1998 [[Come on Over Tour]] and were featured in two television specials from the tour, ''[[Live (Shania Twain DVD)|Live]]'' and ''[[The Specials (Shania Twain DVD)|The Specials]]'', performing with Twain on the song \"[[Don't Be Stupid (You Know I Love You)]]\".<ref>{{cite AV media notes |title=The Specials (Winter Break / Come On Over) |others=[[Shania Twain]] |year=2001 |url=https://www.amazon.com/Shania-Twain-Specials-Winter-Break/dp/product-description/B00005RIIO |at=Back Cover |type=DVD |publisher=Mercury |id=B00005RIIO |location=Nashville }}</ref>\n\nThe group's members are both instrumentalists and dancers, with several members skilled in fiddle-playing (most notably the band's most famous member, Donnell). The female members of the band often perform [[step-dancing]]-style routines and do most of the singing.\n\n==Members==\n[[File:Leahy.jpg|thumb|Leahy in concert at the Fergus Scottish Festival in 2009]]\nAll members of the band are siblings. Each member has a main role to play in the band; although most play more than one instrument and all step dance. Donnell Leahy is married to Cape Breton fiddler [[Natalie MacMaster]] and Frank is married to champion step dancer Chanda Gibson.\n\nIn 2008, Donnell Leahy and Natalie MacMaster were awarded honorary doctorate degrees by Trent University.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.trentu.ca/convocation/honorarydegree_2008leahy.php |title=Honorary Degree Recipients |publisher=Trent University |accessdate=August 22, 2010 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110609033850/http://www.trentu.ca/convocation/honorarydegree_2008leahy.php |archivedate=June 9, 2011 }}</ref>\n\n*Donnell Leahy \u2014 Fiddle\n*Erin Leahy \u2014 Piano, Guitar, Fiddle, Mandolin, Vocals, Bass\n*Angus Leahy \u2014 Fiddle\n*Maria Leahy \u2014 Guitar, Banjo, Vocals\n*Siobheann Donohue (n\u00e9e Leahy) \u2014 Bass, Vocals, Fiddle\n*Doug Leahy \u2014 Fiddle\n*Denise Flack (n\u00e9e Leahy) \u2014 Vocals\n*Frank Leahy \u2014 Drums\n\nThese three sisters are not currently active in the band's touring schedule.\n*Agnes Enright (n\u00e9e Leahy) \u2014 Keyboards, Step dancer, Vocals\n*Chrissie Quigley (n\u00e9e Leahy) \u2014 Keyboards\n*Julie Leahy \u2014 Vocals\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Albums===\n{|class=\"wikitable\"\n!rowspan=\"2\"|Year\n!rowspan=\"2\"|Album\n!colspan=\"2\"|Chart Positions\n!rowspan=\"2\"|CRIA\n|-\n!width=\"50\"|<small>CAN Country</small>\n!width=\"50\"|<small>CAN</small>\n|-\n|1996\n|''[[Leahy (album)|Leahy]]''\n|align=\"center\"|1\n|align=\"center\"|36\n|align=\"center\"|Platinum\n|-\n|2001\n|''Lakefield''\n|\n|\n|\n|-\n|2004\n|''In All Things''\n|\n|\n|\n|-\n|2006\n|''Leahy Live''\n|\n|\n|\n|-\n|2007\n|''Handmade''\n|\n|\n|\n|-\n|2021\n|''Good Water''\n|\n|\n|\n|}\n\nIn addition, the group released several vinyl LPs and cassettes in the 1980s as The Leahy Family. These self-titled releases were privately pressed and usually sold at their concerts, although ''Christmas with the Leahy Family'' was carried by retailers such as [[A&B Sound]].\n\n===Singles===\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\"|Year\n! rowspan=\"2\"|Title\n! colspan=\"2\"|Chart Positions\n! rowspan=\"2\"|Album\n|-\n! width=\"50\"|<small>CAN Country</small>\n! width=\"50\"|<small>CAN AC</small>\n|-\n| 1986\n| \"You've Got the Fiddle (I've Got the Bow)\"\n| align=\"center\"| 52\n| align=\"center\"| \n| ''On the Move''\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 1997\n| \"The Call to Dance\"\n| align=\"center\"| 26\n| align=\"center\"| 31\n| rowspan=\"2\"| ''Leahy''\n|-\n| \"B Minor\"\n| align=\"center\"| \n| align=\"center\"| \n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2001\n| \"Down That Road\"\n| align=\"center\"| \n| align=\"center\"| \n| rowspan=\"2\"| ''Lakefield''\n|-\n| \"Mission\"\n| align=\"center\"| \n| align=\"center\"| \n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2004\n| \"Chasing Rain\"\n| align=\"center\"| \n| align=\"center\"| \n| rowspan=\"2\"| ''In All Things''\n|-\n| \"Coyote Way\"\n| align=\"center\"| \n| align=\"center\"| \n|}\n\n===Music videos===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n|-\n! White"}],"pages":{"31029369":{"pageid":31029369,"ns":0,"title":"John Paul White","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American musician (born 1972)}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2023}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| background        = person\n| name              = John Paul White\n| image             = John Paul White - UNA (cropped).jpg\n| alt               = John Paul White in a recording studio\n| caption           = White {{circa}} 2018\n| image_size        =\n| birth_name        = John Paul White\n| birth_date        = {{birth date and age|1972|08|4}}\n| birth_place       = [[Muscle Shoals, Alabama]], U.S.\n| origin            = [[Tuscumbia, Alabama]], U.S.\n| instrument        = Vocals, guitar\n| genre             = [[Folk music|Folk]], [[Country music|country]]\n| years_active      = 2008\u2013present\n| label             = [[Single Lock Records|Single Lock]]\n| current_member_of = \n| past_member_of    = [[The Civil Wars]]\n| website           = {{URL|johnpaulwhite.com}}\n}}\n\n'''John Paul White''' (born August 4, 1972) is an American musician and former member of the [[Grammy Award]]-winning duo [[the Civil Wars]].<ref>[https://archive.today/20120731103543/http://www.gactv.com/gac/ar_artists_a-z/article/0,,gac_26071_6036481,00.html The Civil Wars Biography] Great American Country, retrieved March 2, 2012</ref> He restarted his solo career with his 2016 release, ''Beulah''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/aug/11/john-paul-white-beulah-review-spectacularly-gloomy-and-bitter|title=John Paul White: Beulah review \u2013 spectacularly gloomy and bitter|first=Alexis|last=Petridis|date=August 11, 2016|access-date=April 15, 2019|website=Theguardian.com}}</ref>\n\n==Early life==\nWhite was born in [[Muscle Shoals, Alabama]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.jambase.com/band/john-paul-white|title=John Paul White \u2013 Upcoming Shows, Tickets, Reviews, More|date=June 21, 2015|website=JamBase.com|access-date=April 15, 2019}}</ref> and grew up in [[Loretto, Tennessee]], on a chicken farm.<ref>{{Cite magazine|last=Leahey|first=Andrew|date=July 28, 2016|title=See John Paul White's Nostalgic 'What's So' Video|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/see-john-paul-whites-nostalgic-whats-so-video-112038/|access-date=August 10, 2020|magazine=Rolling Stone|language=en-US}}</ref>  He attended Sacred Heart School as well as [[Sacred Heart Catholic Church (Loretto, Tennessee)|Sacred Heart Catholic Church]] in [[Loretto, Tennessee]], as a child and graduated from Loretto High School.  He is the oldest of four children.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/502571/the-civil-wars-billboard-cover-story |title=The Civil Wars: Billboard Cover Story |publisher=Billboard |access-date=August 25, 2013}}</ref>\n\n==Career==\nWhite released his first album independently as the band Nuthin' Fancy. The album was recorded with Jeff Quillen at Rock N Roll Dawg Sound/Studio in his hometown of Loretto, Tennessee.\n\nWhite released the album ''[[The Long Goodbye (John Paul White album)|The Long Goodbye]]'' in 2008. The following year, White joined [[Joy Williams (singer)|Joy Williams]] to form [[The Civil Wars]]. The duo won the [[2012 Grammy Awards]] for Best Folk Album, and Country Performance by a Duo or Group.<ref>[http://www.grammy.com/nominees \"Joy Williams and John Paul White of Civil Wars win Grammys for 'Barton Hollow'\"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120503164723/http://www.grammy.com/nominees |date=May 3, 2012 }} Grammy.com retrieved December 2, 2012</ref>\n\nIn 2015, he contributed the song \"Kyrie\", a duet with [[Emmylou Harris]], to the album ''Mercyland: Hymns for the Rest of Us, Vol. II''.<ref>[https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/hear-emmylou-harris-and-john-paul-whites-spiritual-kyrie-20151112 \"Hear Emmylou Harris and John Paul White's Spiritual 'Kyrie'\"], ''[[Rolling Stone]]'', retrieved April 2, 2016</ref> Then in 2016, White released a solo \"Simple Song\" for the album ''Southern Family'' by [[Dave Cobb]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/therecord/2015/12/17/460056739/hear-a-new-solo-song-by-john-paul-white-of-the-civil-wars |title=Hear A New Solo Song By John Paul White, Formerly of the Civil Wars |publisher=NPR Music |access-date=December 17, 2012}}</ref>\n\nWhite is a co-owner of [[Single Lock Records]], which he founded in his hometown of Florence, Alabama, together with [[Ben Tanner]] (of the [[Alabama Shakes]]) and Florence financial consultant, Will Trapp.  The label has signed multiple artists from the Muscle Shoals area, including the legendary [[Donnie Fritts|\"Funky\" Donnie Fritts]], along with indie standouts like [[Lera Lynn]].  White often collaborates with the artists on the Single Lock label.\n\nHis album ''Beulah'' was released on August 19, 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/therecord/2016/06/09/481258114/songs-we-love-john-paul-white-the-martyr|title=Hear A Song From John Paul White's New Album, 'Beulah'|website=Npr.org|access-date=April 15, 2019}}</ref>\n\nIn 2017, White guested on the song \"It Ain't Over Yet\" with [[Rodney Crowell]] and [[Rosanne Cash]]. The track appeared on Crowell's album ''Close Ties''.\n\nIn 2018, White embarked on a house concert tour to get feedback on new material and in April 2019 released the album ''The Hurting Kind''. The album was a bit of a departure from White's Southern Rock and Americana roots, and was an intentional tribute to the country music he grew up listening to.  White co-wrote \"I Wish I Could Write You a Song\" with \"Whispering\" Bill Anderson, resulting in a distinctly Orbison feel on the track.  White toured in 2019 with several Single Lock artists, including acclaimed newcomer [[Erin Rae]].\n\nIn 2023, White and Williams individually participated in a [[Re-recording (music)|re-recording]] of \"[[Safe & Sound (Taylor Swift song)|Safe & Sound]]\" with [[Taylor Swift]], credited under their individual names.<ref>{{Cite web |last=MacCary |first=Julia |date=March 16, 2023 |title=Taylor Swift Is Dropping Four Unreleased Songs Ahead of Her Eras Tour Start |url=https://variety.com/2023/music/news/taylor-swift-unreleased-new-songs-eras-tour-1235556815/ |access-date=March 16, 2023 |website=Variety |language=en-US}}</ref>\n\n==Personal life==\nWhite lives in [[Florence, Alabama]] with his wife Jenny and their four children.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://observer.com/2017/01/john-paul-white-solo-beulah/|title=Life After the Civil Wars: The Reconstruction of John Paul White|last=Rosenschein|first=Ari|date=January 11, 2017|website=[[The New York Observer]]|access-date=September 24, 2021}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n===Solo===\n*''The Long Goodbye'' (2008) Arkam Records\n*''Beulah'' (2016) Single Lock Records\n*''The Hurting Kind'' This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Nora_O'Connor","to":"Nora O'Connor"}],"pages":{"5432652":{"pageid":5432652,"ns":0,"title":"Nora O'Connor","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American, Chicago-based musician (born 1968)}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n|name                              = Nora O'Connor\n|image                             = Nora_O'Connor_performing_on_2018-10-30_at_the_Hideout_in_Chicago_IL.jpg\n|caption                           = O'Connor performing at [[The Hideout Inn|The Hideout]] on October 30, 2017\n|background                        = solo_singer\n|birth_name                        = Nora O'Connor\n|alias                             = Nora O'Connor Kean\n|birth_date                        = {{birth date and age|1968|4|2}}\n|origin                            = [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], U.S.\n|genre                             = [[Folk music|Folk]], [[Country music|Country]]\n|occupation                        = [[Musician]]\n|years_active                      = 1994\u2013present\n|instrument                        = [[Singing|Vocals]], [[Guitar]]\n|associated_acts                   = [[The Blacks (band)|The Blacks]], [[The Decemberists]], [[Robbie Fulks]], [[Andrew Bird]], [[Kelly Hogan]], The Flat Five\n|label                             = [[Bloodshot Records]]\n}}\n\n'''Nora O\u2019Connor''' (born April 2, 1968) is an American, Chicago-based musician. Though primarily known for her vocals, O'Connor also plays guitar and bass. For much of 2013, O'Connor toured internationally as a singer in [[Iron and Wine]].<ref name=iron/> She also records and performs with longtime collaborator, [[Andrew Bird]].<ref name=chicagomag/> O'Connor plays bass and sings back-up for [[Kelly Hogan]] (supporting Hogan's release \"I Like To Keep Myself In Pain\" on [[ANTI- Records]])<ref name=anti/> and in 2010, [[Wilco]]'s [[Jeff Tweedy]] enlisted O'Connor and Hogan as primary vocalists on gospel legend [[Mavis Staples]]\u2019 Grammy Award-winning album ''[[You Are Not Alone (Mavis Staples album)|You Are Not Alone]]''.<ref name=chicagomag/> In the studio and on the stage, O'Connor has backed (among others) [[Neko Case]],<ref name=Neko/> [[Jakob Dylan]],<ref name=billboard/> [[The New Pornographers]],<ref name=billboard/> [[The Decemberists]],<ref name=Decemberists/> [[Archer Prewitt]],<ref name=billboard/> [[John Wesley Harding (singer)|John Wesley Harding]],<ref name=billboard/> [[Hushdrops]],<ref name=Hushdrops/> [[Justin Roberts (musician)|Justin Roberts]]<ref name=Justin/> and [[Robbie Fulks]].<ref name=trib/><ref name=chicago.gov/><ref name=timeout/>\n\nO'Connor has released two solo CDs.  The first, ''Cerulean Blue'', was released by Uncommon Ground Coffeehouse in Chicago in 1996.  The second, ''Til the dawn'', was released by [[Bloodshot Records]] on August 24, 2004. NOTE: In 2022 Nora announced: \"My new album 'My Heart' comes out October 7, 2022 on Pravda Records.\"\n\nIn the mid-1990s, she formed the Nora O'Connor Band, with herself on lead vocals and guitar, Lisa Wertman Crowe on bass and vocals, Tony Ventura on guitar and Mark Cameron on drums.\n\nO'Connor has two sons, and lives in [[Evanston, Illinois]].\n\n== Other collaborative projects ==\n* '''[[The Blacks (band)|The Blacks]]''': Five-piece [[insurgent country]] band (1993\u20132000)\n* '''[[The Decemberists (band)|The Decemberists]]''', touring band: backing vocals, guitar\u00a0(2014\u2013present)\n''See also [[Kelly Hogan#Other projects|Kelly Hogan\u00a7#Other projects]]''.\n\n== Partial discography ==\n\n=== Solo ===\n*''Cerulean Blue'' (1996, Uncommon 2019}}</ref>\n<ref name=Hushdrops>{{cite web\n| first       = Mark\n| last        = Guarino\n| title       = Chicago's Funeral Bonsai Wedding Debut A Hypnotic Bending Of Jazz And Roots; Hushdrops Get Epic\n| date        = Sep 11, 2014\n| website     = [[Chicago Sun-Times]]\n| url         = http://entertainment.suntimes.com/entertainment-news/chicagos-funeral-bonsai-wedding-debut-hypnotic-bending-jazz-roots-hushdrops-get-epic/\n| archiveurl  = https://web.archive.org/web/20141224185121/http://entertainment.suntimes.com/entertainment-news/chicagos-funeral-bonsai-wedding-debut-hypnotic-bending-jazz-roots-hushdrops-get-epic/\n| archivedate = December 24, 2014\n| accessdate  = Mar 25, 2019}}</ref>\n<ref name=Decemberists>{{cite web\n| first       = Scott\n| last        = Mervis\n| title       = 'I'm losing my voice,' singer tells crowd, but Decemberists power through at the Benedum\n| date        = Jun 1, 2018\n| website     = [[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]\n| url         = https://www.post-gazette.com/ae/music/2018/06/01/The-Decemberists-review-Pittsburgh-Benedum-Colin-Meloy-loses-his-voice/stories/201806010106\n| accessdate  = Mar 25, 2019}}</ref>\n<ref name=timeout>{{cite web\n| title       = Chicago musicians think back on their favorite Fleetwood Mac songs.\n| website     = [[Time Out (magazine)|Time Out]]\n| url         = https://www.timeout.com/chicago/music/fleetwood-mac-at-united-center-concert-preview\n| accessdate  = Apr 1, 2019}}</ref>\n<ref name=chicago.gov>{{cite web\n| title       = Fifth Star Bios - 2017 Honorees\n| website     = chicago.gov\n| url         = https://www.chicago.gov/city/en/depts/dca/supp_info/fifthstar0.html\n| accessdate  = Apr 1, 2019}}</ref>\n}}\n\n== External links ==\n*
