Dylan's third full length book, ''[[The Philosophy of Modern Song]]'', which contains 66 essays on songs by other artists, was published on November 1, 2022. Dylan has also been the subject of numerous biographies and critical studies.\n==Discography==\n{{Main|Bob Dylan discography|List of songs written by Bob Dylan}}\n{{Div col|colwidth=25em}}\n* ''[[Bob and Rowdy Ways]]'' (2020)\n* ''[[Shadow Kingdom]]'' (2023)\n{{div col end}}\n\n== Notes ==\n{{reflist|group=a|colwidth=30em}}\n\n== References ==\n=== Citations ===\n{{reflist}}\n\n=== Sources mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Ian_&_Sylvia","to":"Ian & Sylvia"}],"pages":{"506388":{"pageid":506388,"ns":0,"title":"Ian & Sylvia","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|Canadian musical duo}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| image             = Ian and Sylvia 1968.JPG\n| background      = group_or_band\n| name            = Ian & Sylvia\n| years_active    = 1959\u20131975\n| origin          = [[Toronto]], Ontario, Canada\n| genre           = [[Folk music|Folk]], [[Country music|country]], [[country rock]]\n| label           = [[Vanguard Records|Vanguard]], [[MGM Records|MGM]], [[Columbia Records|Columbia]]\n| associated_acts = [[Great Speckled Bird (band)|Great Speckled Bird]]\n| past_members    = [[Ian Tyson]]<br />[[Sylvia Tyson]]\n}}\n\n'''Ian & Sylvia''' were a Canadian [[folk music|folk]] and [[country music|country]] music duo which consisted of [[Ian Tyson|Ian]] and [[Sylvia Tyson]]. They began performing together in 1959 (full-time in 1961),<ref name=\"ReferenceA\">{{cite web|url=https://canadianmusichalloffame.ca/inductee/ian-sylvia/|title=Ian & Sylvia \u2013 Canadian Music Hall Of Fame|website=Canadianmusichalloffame.ca|access-date=February 11, 2020}}</ref> married in 1964, and divorced and stopped performing together in 1975.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.quartette.com/tyson.html |title=Tyson |publisher=Quartette |date=2003-09-08 |access-date=2012-04-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine | title=Tyson Takes a New 'Road' | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vhQEAAAAMBAJ&q=%22Tyson+Takes+a+New+'Road'%22+billboard&pg=PA52 | first=Larry | last=Leblanc | magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] | date=12 February 2005 | page=52 | access-date=2010-04-09}}</ref><ref name=ce>{{cite encyclopedia|author=Historica Canada|author-link=Historica Canada|url=https://thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/ian-and-sylvia-emc|title=Ian and Sylvia|encyclopedia=[[Encyclopedia of Music in Canada]]|access-date=September 1, 2019}}</ref>\n\n==History==\n===Early lives===\n[[Ian Tyson]], [[Order of Canada|CM]], [[Alberta Order of Excellence|AOE]] was born in Victoria, British Columbia in 1933. In his teens, he decided upon a career as a [[rodeo]] rider. Recovering from injuries sustained from a fall during the mid-1950s, he started learning guitar. In the late 1950s, he relocated to Toronto, aspiring to a career as a commercial artist. He also started playing clubs and coffeehouses in Toronto.<ref name=\"ch\">{{cite web|url=http://tceplus.com/index.cfm?PgNm=TCE&Params=U1ARTU0000752|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051205043718/http://tceplus.com/index.cfm?PgNm=TCE&Params=U1ARTU0000752|url-status=dead|title=Coffeehouses|archive-date=December 5, 2005}}</ref> By 1959 he was performing music as a full-time occupation.\n\n[[Sylvia Tyson]], n\u00e9e Fricker, CM, was born in Chatham, Ontario in 1940. While still in her teens, she started frequenting the folk clubs of Toronto.\n\n===Career===\n====Folk duo====\nThe two started performing together in Toronto in 1959. By 1962, they were living in New York City, where they caught the attention of manager [[Albert Grossman]],<ref>{{cite web|author=Gilliland, John. |url=https://digital.library.unt.edu/ark:/67531/metadc1692106/m1/#track/9 |title=Pop Chronicles Interviews #184 - Ian and Sylvia Tyson - All Tracks UNT Digital Library |publisher=Digital.library.unt.edu |date=1968-01-12 |accessdate=2021-03-02}}</ref> who managed [[Peter, Paul and Mary]] and would soon become [[Bob Dylan]]'s manager. Grossman secured them a contract with [[Vanguard Records]] and they released their first album late in the year.<ref name=\"canadianmusichalloffame.ca\"/>\n\nTheir first album, self-titled ''Ian & Sylvia'', on Vanguard Records consists mainly of traditional songs.<ref>{{cite magazine|date=August 25, 1962|magazine=Billboard|publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc.|page=24|title=Ian & Sylvia|issn=0006-2510}}</ref> There were British and Canadian folk songs, spiritual music, and a few [[blues]] songs thrown into the mix. The album was moderately successful and they made the list of performers for the 1963 [[Newport Folk Festival]].\n\n''Four Strong Winds'', their second album, was similar to the first, with the exception of the inclusion of the early Dylan composition \"[[Tomorrow Is a Long Time]]\" and the title song \"[[Four Strong Winds]]\", written by Ian Tyson. \"Four Strong Winds\" was a major hit in Canada and ensured their stardom.<ref>[http://www.webfitz.com/lyrics/Charts/1963/Ch196310.html 30 Years of Canadian Chart Listings] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.today/20021102214504/http://www.webfitz.com/lyrics/Charts/1963/Ch196310.html |date=2002-11-02 }} - #9 on 28 October 1963</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=Ian & Sylvia|date=October 19, 1963|journal=Billboard Magazine|page=18|issn=0006-2510}}</ref> Years later, the song was named as the greatest Canadian song of all time by the CBC-Radio program ''50 Tracks: The Canadian Version''.<ref name=\"ReferenceA\"/>\n\nThe two married in June 1964; they also released their third album, ''Northern Journey'', that year. It included a song written by Sylvia, titled \"[[You Were on My Mind]]\", recorded by both the California group [[We Five]] (a 1965 #4 on the [[RPM (magazine)|RPM]] charts, #1 on the Cashbox chart, #3 on the Billboard Hot 100) and British [[folk rock]] singer [[Crispian St. Peters]] (#29 on the [[RPM (magazine)|RPM]] charts, #36 in 1967).<ref>Joel Whitburn, ''Billboard Book of Top 40 Hits''</ref> A recording of \"Four Strong Winds\" by [[Bobby Bare]] made it to #3 on the [[country music|country]] charts around that time.\n\nOn the ''Northern Journey'' album was the song \"[[Someday Soon (Ian Tyson song)|Someday Soon]]\", a composition by Ian Tyson that would rival \"Four Strong Winds\" in its popularity. (Both songs would eventually be recorded by dozens of singers.)\n\nTheir fourth album, ''Early Morning Rain'', consisted in large part of new songs. They introduced the work of the couple's fellow Canadian songwriter and performer [[Gordon Lightfoot]] through the title song and \"(That's What You Get) For Lovin' Me\". They also included the first recording of the song \"[[Darcy Farrow]]\" by [[Steve Gillette]] and Tom Campbell, as well as a number of their own compositions.\n \nThey performed at the [[1965 Newport Folk Festival]].<ref name=pc32>{{Pop Chronicles |32| 1}}</ref> ''Play One More'', their offering of 1965, showed a move toward the electrified folk-like music that was becoming popular with groups like [[the Byrds]] and [[the Lovin' Spoonful]]. The title tune used horns to evoke the [[mariachi]] style.\n\nIn 1967, they released two albums, one recorded for Vanguard, the other for [[MGM]]. These two efforts, ''So Much For Dreaming'' and ''Lovin' Sound'', were far less dynamic presentations.\n\nFrom 1970 to 1975, Ian Tyson hosted ''The Ian Tyson Show'' on [[CTV Television Network|CTV]], known as ''Nashville North'' in its first season. Sylvia Tyson and the Great Speckled Bird appeared often on the series.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.tvarchive.ca/database/17889/ian_tyson_show,_the/details/ | title=Ian Tyson Show, The (Series) (1970-1975) |date=February 2003 | access-date=July 18, 2019 | publisher=TV Archive}}</ref>\n\n====Country rock pioneers====\nThey moved to Nashville, Tennessee, where they recorded two albums; one to fulfill the terms of their Vanguard contract, the other to supply MGM with a second (and last) album for that label. The albums can be defined as early [[country rock]] music; ''Nashville'' for Vanguard was cut in February 1968, one month before the Byrds' ''[[Sweetheart of the Rodeo]]'', widely considered the first collaboration of rock and Nashville players.<ref name=\"Rolling Stone-Nashville\"/> Three of Bob Dylan's ''[[Basement Tapes]]'' songs are included on their Nashville albums; most of the rest were written by Ian or Sylvia.<ref name=\"Rolling Stone-Nashville\">{{cite magazine | url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/inside-ian-sylvias-nashville-country-rocks-great-lost-album-20150722 | title=Inside Ian & Sylvia's 'Nashville,' Country-Rock's Great Lost Album | magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] | date=July 22, 2015 | access-date=October 11, 2016 | author=Browne, David | author-link=David Browne (journalist)}}</ref>\n\nIn 1969, Ian & Sylvia formed the [[country rock]] group [[Great Speckled Bird (band)|Great Speckled Bird]]. In addition to participating in the cross-Canada rock-and-roll rail tour [[Festival Express]], they recorded [[Great Speckled Bird (album)|a self-titled album]] for the short-lived [[Ampex]] label. Produced by [[Todd Rundgren]], the record failed when Ampex was unable to establish widespread distribution. Thousands of copies never left the warehouse, and it has become a much sought-after collector's item. Initially, the album artist was given as Great Speckled Bird but later copies had a sticker saying that it featured the duo.\n\nIan & Sylvia's last two albums were recorded on [[Columbia Records]]. The first, 1971's ''Ian and Sylvia'' (not to be confused with their 1962 self-titled release) consists largely of mainstream country-flavored songs. This album was released on CD, with extra tracks, as ''The Beginning of the End'' in 1996.<ref>{{cite web |url={{AllMusic|class=album|id=r245993|pure_url=yes}}|title=''The Beginning of the End''|website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=2012-04-04}}</ref> Their second Columbia record, 1972's ''You Were on My Mind'', featured a later incarnation of Great Speckled Bird. The songs range from hard country rock to middle-of-the-road country material. Neither of the Columbia albums sold well. They were eventually combined and released as 1974's ''The Best of Ian and Sylvia''.\n\nIn 1972, Ian & Sylvia performed the song \"Let Her Alone\" for [[The Walt Disney Company|Walt Disney Productions]]' live-action drama ''[[Run, Cougar, Run]]''. Ian also served as the film's narrator.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://every70smovie.blogspot.com/2016/08/run-cougar-run-1972.html|title=Every 70s Movie: Run, Cougar, Run (1972)|first=Peter|last=Hanson|website=Every70smovie.blogspot.com|date=August 18, 2016}}</ref>\n\nBy 1975, Ian & Sylvia had stopped performing together and soon afterwards were divorced. Their final appearance as a duo was in May 1975 at the [[Horseshoe Tavern]] in Toronto.<ref name=ce/>\n\n===Post-divorce===\nAfter their marriage ended in 1975, Ian returned to Southern Alberta to farm and train horses, but continued his musical career. His autobiography ''The Long Trail: My Life in the West'' was published in 2010.<ref name=\"auto\">{{cite web|url=https://www.ccma.org/cgi/page.cgi/hall_of_fame_inductees.html?log=view&log_id=15|title=Hall of Fame Inductees - Canadian Country Music Association|website=Ccma.org|access-date=February 11, 2020|archive-date=March 18, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170318151056/http://www.ccma.org/cgi/page.cgi/hall_of_fame_inductees.html?log=view&log_id=15|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref name=\"canadianmusichalloffame.ca\"/>\n\nSylvia wrote, performed, and involved herself in various projects. In recent years, she has been recording new material, working as a member of the group [[Quartette (band)|Quartette]], and performing a one-woman show titled ''River Road and Other Stories''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.quartette.com/subsets/ST_review_index.htm|title=Sylvia Tyson's One Woman Show - River Road & Other Stories|website=Quartette.com|access-date=February 11, 2020}}</ref>\n\nThe duo's son, Clay Tyson (Clayton Dawson Tyson,<ref name=LovinSound-notes-Clayton>\"They're partners in life as well as in music, which must have its difficult moments like the prospect of having to sing with someone you were maybe not speaking to. But they certainly have made that work, what with that thing rolling around on the rug, young Clayton Dawson, herein and hereafter referred to as 'Mr. Spoons.'\" From the jacket notes (by John Court) to Ian and Sylvia's LP \"Lovin' Sound\", MGM 4388, 1967. Quoted in [http://www.mudcat.org/thread.cfm?threadid=10363#71474 Mudcat Forum] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120320172248/http://www.mudcat.org/thread.cfm?threadid=10363#71474 |date=2012-03-20 }} by Dale Rose, 1999-04-16; accessed 2011-05-08.</ref> born 1966),<ref name=LivLegClay>{{cite web | url=http://www.livinglegendsmusic.com/library.php?personID=4942 | title=Clay Tyson | publisher=Living Legends Music | date=2006\u20132008 | access-date=2011-04-19 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111005012132/http://www.livinglegendsmusic.com/library.php?personID=4942 | archive-date=2011-10-05 | url-status=dead }}</ref> is also a musician and recording artist.\n\nOn August 16, 1986, folk singers who had recorded or written Ian and Sylvia songs, reunited for a concert that was filmed for the CBC. The group at the Kingswood Music Theatre in Maple, Ontario included [[Gordon Lightfoot]], [[Judy Collins]], [[Emmylou Harris]], and [[Murray McLauchlan]].<ref name=ce/>\n\nIan & Sylvia sang their signature song \"Four Strong Winds\" at the 50th anniversary of the [[Mariposa Folk Festival]] on July 11, 2010, in Orillia, Ontario.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/arts/books-and-media/four-strong-winds-ian-sylvia-by-john-einarson-with-ian-tyson-and-sylvia-tyson/article4256234/|title=Four Strong Winds: Ian & Sylvia by John Einarson with Ian Tyson and Sylvia Tyson|newspaper=The Globe and Mail|date=9 September 2011 }}</ref>\n\n==Honours==\nIn 1992, they were inducted into the [[Canadian Music Hall of Fame]].<ref name=\"ReferenceA\"/>\n\nIn 1994, they were both made Members of the [[Order of Canada]].<ref name=\"ReferenceA\"/>\n\nIn 2005, an extensive Canadian Broadcasting Corporation poll on the CBC-Radio program ''50 Tracks: The Canadian Version'' named \"[[Four Strong Winds]]\" to be the greatest Canadian song of all time. Artists [[Neil Young]], [[Johnny Cash]], [[Sarah McLachlan]], [[Harry Belafonte]], and Bob Dylan recorded this song.<ref name=\"canadianmusichalloffame.ca\">{{cite web |date=2017 |title=Hall of Fame Inductees |url= https://www.ccma.org/cgi/page.cgi/hall_of_fame_inductees.html |work= CCMA: Canadian Country Music Association |location= Toronto |access-date= 17 July 2019 | archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20170317192340/http://www.ccma.org/cgi/page.cgi/hall_of_fame_inductees.html | archive-date= 17 March 2017 | url-status= live| quote= Tyson is a recipient of the Order of Canada and in 2005 CBC Radio One listeners chose his song, \u2018Four Strong Winds\u2019 as the greatest Canadian song of all time, during a radio series titled \u201c50 Tracks: The Canadian Version\u201d.}}</ref>\n\nIn 2006, they were both inducted into the Mariposa Hall of Fame; the duo performed a song together at that time, long after they had gone their separate ways.<ref name=\"ReferenceA\"/> Back in 1961, Ian and Sylvia had headlined at the [[Mariposa Folk Festival]].\n\nIn a poll of the [[Western Writers of America]], two Ian & Sylvia songs, \"Someday Soon\" and \"Summer Wages\" (both written by Tyson), were selected among the \"Top 100 Western Songs\" of all time.<ref name=\"Top100\">{{cite web|title=The Top 100 Western Songs |author=Western Writers of America |year=2010 |author-link=Western Writers of America |publisher=American Cowboy |url=http://www.americancowboy.com/culture/top-100-western-songs |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101019002745/http://americancowboy.com/culture/top-100-western-songs |archive-date=19 October 2010 |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n\nIan Tyson was inducted into the Canadian Country Music Hall of Fame in 1989.<ref name=\"auto\"/> Sylvia Tyson was inducted in 2003.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ccma.org/cgi/page.cgi/hall_of_fame_inductees.html?log=view&log_id=34|title=Hall of Fame Inductees - Canadian Country Music Association|website=Ccma.org|access-date=February 11, 2020|archive-date=March 18, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170318151627/http://www.ccma.org/cgi/page.cgi/hall_of_fame_inductees.html?log=view&log_id=34|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n\nIn July 2019, it was announced that Ian Tyson and Sylvia Tyson would be inducted into the [[Canadian Songwriters Hall of Fame]] individually, not as a duo. The Canadian Broadcasting Corporation stated that its 1964 hit \"Four Strong Winds\" \"has been deemed one of the most influential songs in Canadian history\". The report also referenced the song \"You Were on My Mind\", written by Sylvia Tyson, as well as her four albums from 1975 to 1980.<ref>{{cite news |last=Friend |first=David |url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/entertainment/ian-tyson-sylvia-tyson-canadian-songwriters-hall-of-fame-1.5215382 |title=Ian Tyson and Sylvia Tyson to be inducted separately into Canadian Songwriters Hall of Fame |website=CBC |date=July 17, 2019 |access-date=July 12, 2020}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Album<ref>{{cite Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Mary_Gauthier","to":"Mary Gauthier"}],"pages":{"3180998":{"pageid":3180998,"ns":0,"title":"Mary Gauthier","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n\n{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Musicians -->\n| name             = Mary Gauthier\n| image            = Mary Gauthier 2006.jpg\n| caption          = Gauthier in 2006\n| image_size       = \n| landscape        = \n| background       = solo_singer <!-- includes singer-songwriters -->\n| birth_name       = \n| alias            =\n| birth_date       = {{birth date and age|1962|3|11}}\n| birth_place      = [[New Orleans]], Louisiana, United States\n| instrument       = Vocals, guitar\n| genre            = {{Flatlist|\n*[[Folk music|Folk]]\n*[[Country music|country]]\n*[[Americana (music)|Americana]]}}\n| occupation       = Songwriter, musician, writing teacher, restaurateur\n| years_active     = 1990\u2013present\n| label            = [[Lost Highway Records|Lost Highway]], In the Black, [[Signature Sounds Recordings|Signature Sounds]], [[Proper Records|Proper]]\n| website          = {{URL|www.marygauthier.com/}}\n}}\n\n'''Mary Veronica Gauthier''' ({{IPAc-en|\u02c8|\u0261|o\u028a|\u0283|e\u026a}} {{respell|GOH|shay}}; born March 11, 1962) is a [[Grammy Awards|Grammy]]-nominated American [[folk music|folk]] singer-songwriter and author, whose songs have been covered by performers including [[Tim McGraw]], [[Blake Shelton]], [[Kathy Mattea]], [[Boy George]], [[Jimmy Buffett]], [[Bettye Lavette]], [[Candi Staton]], and [[Amy Helm]].\n\nMary's songs often deal with marginalization, informed by her experience of adoption, addiction and recovery, and growing up gay in the deep south. Her work demonstrates an \"ability to transform her own trauma into a purposeful and communal narrative\", such as the lyric \"we could all use, a little mercy, now\", from her song \"[[Mercy Now]]\".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2018/01/27/580429847/reworking-trauma-mary-gauthier-tells-veteran-stories-on-rifles-rosary-beads|title = Reworking Trauma: Mary Gauthier Tells Veteran Stories on 'Rifles & Rosary Beads'| website=NPR.org }}</ref>\n\nHer Grammy nominated 2018 album ''Rifles & Rosary Beads'', co-written with military veterans and their families, has been hailed as a landmark achievement.<ref name=\"countrystandardtime.com\">{{Cite web|url=https://www.countrystandardtime.com/d/cdreview.asp?xid=6603|title = Mary Gauthier - Rifles and Rosary Beads}}</ref>\n\nShe has won awards from the  Americana Music Association, International Folk Music Awards, the Independent Music Awards, the GLAMA Awards, and the UK Americana Association.\n\n==Early life, addiction and sobriety==\nGauthier was born in 1962 in [[New Orleans]], Louisiana, to a mother who gave her to St Vincent's Women and Infants Asylum, where she spent the first year of her life.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://explore.baltimoreheritage.org/items/show/467|title = St. Vincent's Infant Asylum}}</ref> In adulthood, Mary spoke to her biological mother once by phone, but there was no further contact between them.<ref name=\"independent.co.uk\">{{Cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/features/mary-gauthier-hottest-star-country-music-6103582.html|title=Mary Gauthier: The hottest star in country music|website=[[Independent.co.uk]] |date=April 2009}}</ref> She was adopted by an [[Italian American|Italian]] [[Roman Catholic Church|Catholic]] couple from [[Thibodaux, Louisiana|Thibodaux]], Louisiana. Her father was an alcoholic.<ref>{{Citation\n  | last = Gold\n  | first = Scott\n  | title = Change of tune\n  | newspaper = [[Los Angeles Times]]\n  | date = June 12, 2008\n| url = http://www.timesunion.com/AspStories/story.asp?storyID=695464&category=ARTS&newsdate=6/12/2008\n  | access-date =January 27, 2010\n}}\n</ref> Struggling with a variety of issues, Gauthier left home young and abused drugs and alcohol, as did her brother, who was three years younger and also adopted.<ref name=Reighley>{{Citation\n  | last = Reighley\n  | first = Kurt B.\n  | title = Singing her stories\n  | newspaper = [[The Advocate (LGBT magazine)|The Advocate]]\n  | page = 65\n  | date = March 29, 2005\n| url = https://books.google.com/books?id=-GMEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA65\n  | access-date =January 27, 2010\n}}\n</ref> He was later jailed for armed robbery. Mary says she had drunk herself unconscious on sloe gin by the time she was twelve.<ref name=\"independent.co.uk\"/>\n\nWhen she was fifteen she ran away from home, recalling that \"I was a gay kid, and back then, that just didn\u2019t fly. Back then, gay kids were beat up, abused, some ended up taking their own lives. It was horrible, and I just wanted to get away.\u201d<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thetiesthatbindus.org/mary-gauthier-im-so-glad-ive-remained-willing-to-do-what-it-takes/|title = Mary Gauthier: 'I'm so glad I've remained willing to do what it takes'| newspaper=The Ties That Bind Us |date = 20 August 2018}}</ref> Mary spent the next several years in [[drug rehabilitation]], [[halfway house]]s, living with friends, and spent her eighteenth birthday in a jail cell.<ref name=Reighley /> These experiences provided fodder for her songwriting later on.\n\nSpurred on by friends, she enrolled at [[Louisiana State University]] as a philosophy major, dropping out during her senior year. After attending the [[Cambridge School of Culinary Arts]], and working in an upmarket restaurant, she got financial backing to open a [[Cajun cuisine|Cajun]] restaurant in Boston's [[Back Bay, Boston, Massachusetts|Back Bay]] neighborhood, calling it Dixie Kitchen.<ref name=tucker>{{Citation |last=Tucker |first=Karen Iris |title=Mary, quite contrary |newspaper=[[The Advocate (LGBT magazine)|The Advocate]] |pages=83 |date=November 7, 2000 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=l2MEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA83 |access-date=January 27, 2010 }}\n</ref> On opening night, 12 July 1990, she was arrested for drunk driving and has been sober ever since. \"I eventually got sober when I was twenty seven years old... I started writing songs in earnest at around thirty two years of age\", she says.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.marygauthier.com/news/behind-the-song-i-drink|title=Behind the Song: I Drink|date=3 February 2013 }}</ref> After achieving sobriety from \"[mainly] alcohol, cocaine and heroin\", Mary continued to manage, and cook at, the restaurant but was increasingly driven to dedicate herself to songwriting.<ref name=\"independent.co.uk\"/><ref>{{Citation\n  | last = Alarik\n  | first = Scott\n  | title = Truth be told&nbsp;\u2014 Mary Gauthier doesn't shy away from her past\n  | newspaper = [[The Boston Globe]]\n  | date = October 7, 2005\n| url = http://www.boston.com/news/globe/living/articles/2005/10/07/truth_be_told/\n  | access-date =January 27, 2010\n}}</ref>\n\n==Music career==\nHaving recorded her debut, ''Dixie Kitchen'', Gauthier sold her share in the restaurant to finance her second album. ''Drag Queens in Limousines'' was released in 1998, winning several accolades, and led to appearances at eleven major folk festivals, including [[Newport Folk Festival|Newport]].<ref name=tucker /> After moving to [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]] in 2001, she secured a publishing deal with [[Harlan Howard|Harlan Howard Songs]], followed by her third album, ''Filth and Fire'', in 2002.<ref name= quillen>Quillen, Shay (March 4, 2005). \"[https://www.newspapers.com/image/219324180/ Mary Gauthier's music provides soundtrack to bleak childhood]\". ''Knight Ridder Tribune News''. The Times (Shreveport, Louisiana). p. 3D.</ref> Two years later, she landed a record deal with [[Lost Highway Records|Lost Highway]], a division of [[Universal Music]], and released the first of two albums with them.<ref name= quillen/>\n\n===Mercy Now===\n''Mercy Now'' won widespread acclaim and propelled Mary into the spotlight, making the Top Ten Albums list in many publications.<ref>\"[https://www.newspapers.com/image/239744913/ Most memorable in pop music]\". ''The Los Angeles Times''. p. E1, E28.</ref><ref>\"[https://www.newspapers.com/image/456044465/ Patrick Langston's Top 10 Country & Roots Albums]\". ''The Ottawa Citizen''. December 31, 2005. p. F3.</ref><ref>\"[https://www.newspapers.com/image/239749429/ 2005: Shaken & Stirred: Pop Music: Critic's Top 10 Lists]\". ''Los Angeles Times''. December 22, 2005. p. E48.</ref><ref>Hilburn, Robert (December 31, 2005). \"[https://www.newspapers.com/image/497549741/ Singles chart of '05 had some moving moments]\". ''The Vancouver Sun''. p. E4.</ref><ref>Jorgensen, Chris (December 23, 2005). \"[https://www.newspapers.com/image/415637281/ Old hands and up-and-comers]\". ''The Billings Gazette''. p. 8D.</ref><ref>Curtin, Mike (December 31, 2005). \"[https://www.newspapers.com/image/348302851/ Albumbs of the Year]\". ''The Post-Star'' (Glens Falls, New York). p. D8.</ref><ref>Chun, Gary C.W. (December 29, 2005). \"[https://www.newspapers.com/image/273568704/ Top albums of 2005 cross cultural borders]\". ''Honolulu Star-Bulletin''. p. D1, D4.</ref><ref>Shapiro, Bill (December 15, 2005). \"[https://www.newspapers.com/image/688516528/ The Year in Music]\". ''The Kansas City Star''. p. 15.</ref><ref>Simmons, Carol (December 2, 2005). \"[https://www.newspapers.com/image/411254213/ Best CDs of 2005]\". ''Dayton Daily News'' (Dayton, Ohio). p. 17.</ref><ref>Bledsoe, Wayne (December 30, 2005). \"[https://www.newspapers.com/image/777244874/ Music: Top Ten]\". ''The Knoxville News-Sentinel''. p. 5.</ref> A second album for Lost Highway, ''Between Daylight and Dark'', followed in 2007.<ref>Gamboa, Glenn (November 8, 2007). \"[https://www.newspapers.com/image/407440867/ Mary Gauthier 'Between Daylight and Dark']\". ''Wisconsin State Journal''. p. 9.</ref> Gauthier's next studio record, ''[[The Foundling (album)|The Foundling]]'' (2010), was released by [[Razor & Tie Records]].<ref>Bledsoe, Wayne (May 30, 2010). \"[https://www.newspapers.com/image/777464437/ Gauthier goes deep on 'The Foundling']\". ''The Knoxville News-Sentinel''. p. E5.</ref> She then made the first of several albums for In The Black Records, ''LIVE at Blue Rock'' (2013), her first live album which was recorded at a ranch outside of [[Austin, Texas]].<ref>Harde, Erin (July 4, 2013). \"[https://www.newspapers.com/image/498793421/ Gauthier caught lightning in a bottle]\". ''The Leader-Post''. p. 11.</ref>\n\nMary's eighth studio album, ''Trouble and Love'' (2014), demonstrated her now familiar \"brutal honesty balanced by rough-hewn tenderness\" to great effect.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/trouble-love-mw0002657958|title = Trouble & Love - Mary Gauthier| website=[[AllMusic]] }}</ref> The following year, Gauthier featured on Eight 30 Records' ''Cold and Bitter Tears: The Songs of [[Ted Hawkins]]'', contributing her take on the late Los Angeles busker's signature song, ''Sorry You're Sick''.<ref>Lewis, Randy (October 21, 2015). \"[https://www.newspapers.com/image/203641158/ Venice busker's legacy lives on]\". ''The Los Angeles Times''. p. E1, E11.</ref>\n\n===''Rifles & Rosary Beads''===\nGauthier's next record, ''Rifles & Rosary Beads'' (2018), was co-written with U.S. veterans and their families, arising out of Mary's involvement with the [[SongwritingWith:Soldiers|Songwriting With Soldiers]] program. Mary notes that \"[every] day, on average, twenty-two veterans commit suicide\", adding that \"[underneath] so much of the problems in the world is trauma, it's the central issue humanity is dealing with. We've found something powerful here, that brings hope to people who are hurting\".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.marygauthier.com/about|title = About}}</ref>\n\nThe album was released to widespread acclaim, and has been described as \"music that's just plain important\" (''[[The LA Times]]''), and as being \"not only the strongest album of her career but, in its own way, a landmark album.\"<ref name=\"countrystandardtime.com\"/><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.latimes.com/entertainment/music/la-et-ms-mary-gauthier-mccabes-review-20181209-story.html|title = Mary Gauthier taps 'Rifles & Rosary Beads' songs written with vets in McCabe's performance| website=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date = 9 December 2018}}</ref> It has won several awards, and secured Mary her first Grammy nomination.\n\n==Accolades, awards and influence==\nAlthough rarely in the pop/mainstream spotlight, throughout her career Gauthier has won widespread acclaim and numerous awards for her songs. In 2000, ''Drag Queens in Limousines'' won Best Folk/Singer-Songwriter Song at the first Independent Music Awards. Gauthier was nominated for Best New Artist at the [[Boston Music Awards]], and also for three Gay and Lesbian American Music Awards (GLAMAs), winning best country artist. In 2002, ''Filth and Fire'' was named Best Indy CD of the Year by [[Jon Pareles]] of ''The New York Times''. ''Mercy Now'' made the 2003 Top Ten Albums list in ''[[The New York Times]]'', ''[[The LA Times]]'', ''[[The Daily News (New York)|The Daily News]]'', and ''[[Billboard Magazine]]'', and was voted the No.&nbsp;6 Record of the Decade by ''[[No Depression (magazine)|No Depression]]'' magazine.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nodepression.com/article/no-depression-communitys-top-20-albums-decade |title=The No Depression Community's Top 20 Albums of the Decade \u2013 No Depression Americana and Roots Music |publisher=Nodepression.com |date=December 2, 2009|access-date=February 24, 2016}}</ref> Gauthier was named New/Emerging Artist of the Year by the [[Americana Music Association]] in 2005.<ref>McCall, Michael (July 31, 2005). \"[https://www.newspapers.com/image/192767218/ To tell her truth]\". ''The Los Angeles Times''. p. E38.</ref>\n\n''The Foundling'' was named the No.&nbsp;3 Record of the Year by ''The LA Times'' music writer Randy Lewis, in 2010.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/music_blog/2010/12/times-music-writers-pick-their-best-albums-of-the-year.html | work=Los Angeles Times | title=Times music writers pick their favorite albums of 2010 | date=December 21, 2010}}</ref> In 2015, Gauthier was nominated for the Outstanding Music Artist of the Year at the 26th Annual [[GLAAD]] Media Awards. ''Rifles & Rosary Beads'' earned Gauthier her first Grammy nomination in the category of [[Best Folk Album]] (2019), and won Album of the Year at The International Folk Music Awards. She was also nominated for Album of the Year at the [[Americana Music Honors & Awards|Americana Music Honors and Awards]], and named International Artist of the Year by the UK Americana Music Association.\n\nNumerous artists have recorded Gauthier's songs, including [[Jimmy Buffett]], [[Tim McGraw]], [[Blake Shelton]], [[Bobby Bare]], [[Boy George]], [[Bill Chambers (musician)|Bill Chambers]], [[Mike Farris (musician)|Mike Farris]], [[Candi Staton]], [[Amy Helm]], [[Kathy Mattea]] and [[Bettye LaVette]]. Mike Farris and Bettye LaVette both received Grammy nominations, LaVette for Best Blues Record (2016) for ''[[Worthy (album)|Worthy]]'', the title track of which was written by Mary Gauthier and [[Beth Nielsen Chapman]]. Farris took home the Grammy for Best Roots Gospel Album (2015) for ''Shine for All the People'', which included Gauthier's song \"Mercy Now\". Her songs have also been featured in several TV shows, including [[Nashville (2012 TV series)|Nashville]] on ABC, Masterpiece Theatre's [[Case Histories (TV series)|Case Histories]], [[Showtime (TV channel)|Showtime]]'s [[Banshee (TV series)|Banshee]], [[HBO]]'s [[Injustice (British TV series)|Injustice]] and Paramount Network's [[Yellowstone (American TV series)|Yellowstone]].\n\nMary's recordings have appeared on playlists by [[Wally Lamb]], [[Tom Waits]] and [[Theme Time Radio Hour Season One#Episode 3: Drinking|Bob Dylan]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/radionational/programs/dailyplanet/2012-03-14/3875066 |title=Tom Waits Guest Presenter \u2013 Daily Planet \u2013 ABC Radio National (Australian Broadcasting Corporation) |date=24 January 2012 |publisher=Abc.net.au |access-date=July 13, 2014}}</ref> She wrote a memoir about the art of songwriting, ''Saved by a Song'' (St. Martin's Press), which was released in 2021.<ref>Bauder, David (Aug 21, 2022). \"[https://www.newspapers.com/image/870431875/ Music Therapy: Mary Gauthier uses songwriting to help people through trauma]\". ''Associated Press''. Port Charlotte Sun' (Port Charlotte, Florida). p. D7.</ref> Mary is a regular on the [[Grand Ole Opry]], and currently resides in Nashville, Tennessee.\n\n==Education, publications and writing==\nMary Gauthier's book, [https://www.amazon.com/Saved-Song-Healing-Power-Songwriting/dp/1250202116 \"Saved by a Song\"] was published in 2021 by St Martin's Press. Mary Gauthier's songs are taught at several universities, including [[Alice Randall]]'s \"Country Lyric in American Culture\u201d class at [[Vanderbilt University]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/kenburns/country-music/alice-randall-biography/|title = Country Music &#124; Alice Randall Biography| website=[[PBS]] }}</ref> Her short stories have been published in several books and magazines, including ''Amplified'' (Random House), ''The Blue Rock Review'', an arts magazine based in [[Wimberley, Texas]], and the ''Capitola Review'', a handcrafted, numbered, limited edition publication.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://sneezingcow.com/2010/12/02/sneezing-cow-auction-items-of-the-day/|title = Sneezing Cow Auction Items of the Day|date = 2 December 2010}}</ref>\n\nGauthier has been featured in various books on country and Americana music, with chapters dedicated to her in \"They Came To Nashville\", by [[Marshall Chapman]], and \"Right By Her Roots: Americana Women and Their Songs\", by Jewly Height. Mary also features in a Dutch book on country music, \"De Bezem Door Nashville (The Broom Through Nashville)\", by Harry de Jong, with photographs by Henk Bleeker.\n\n==Discography==\n* ''Dixie Kitchen'' (1997)\n* ''Drag Queens in Limousines'' (1999)\n* ''Filth and Fire'' (2002)\n* ''[[Mercy Now]]'' (2005)\n* ''Between Daylight and Dark'' (2007)\n* ''Genesis (The Early Years)'' (2008) \u2013 A 15-track compilation from the first three albums\n* ''[[The Foundling (album)|The Foundling]]'' (2010) \u2013 No. 13 ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' Americana chart\n* ''The Foundling Alone'' (2011) \u2013 Acoustic demos of songs in development, from ''The Foundling''\n* ''Live at Blue Rock'' (2012) \u2013 11 mixed new and old tracks plus hidden track, \"Mercy Now\"\n* ''Trouble and Love'' (2014) \u2013 No. 22 Billboard Americana chart\n* ''Rifles & Rosary Beads'' (2018) \u2013 Co-written with U.S. veterans and their families\n* ''Dark Enough to See the Stars'' (2022)\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n* {{Official website|http://www.marygauthier.com/}}\n*
