This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Mindy_Smith","to":"Mindy Smith"}],"pages":{"4003805":{"pageid":4003805,"ns":0,"title":"Mindy Smith","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter (born 1972)}}\n\n{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians -->\n| name                = Mindy Smith\n| image               = Mindysmith1.jpg\n| caption             = Mindy Smith performing in 2005\n| background       = solo_singer\n| birth_name       = \n| birth_date         ={{Birth date and age|1972|6|1|mf=y}}\n| birth_place        = [[Long Island, New York]], U.S.\n| genre               = [[Folk music|Folk]], [[pop music|pop]], [[country music|country]]\n| occupation        = Singer, songwriter\n| instrument        = Guitar, vocals\n| years_active     = 2003\u2013present\n| label                = [[Vanguard Records|Vanguard]]\n| associated_acts =\n| website            = {{URL|www.mindysmithmusic.com}}\n}}\n\n'''Melinda Leigh Smith''' (born June 1, 1972, [[Long Island, New York]]) is an American singer-songwriter. Her first record deal came after she sang a cover version of the song \"[[Jolene (song)|Jolene]]\" by [[Dolly Parton]].\n\n==Music career==\nSmith was adopted at birth by a non-denominational Protestant minister and his wife, who was choir director at the church. She grew up on [[Long Island]], New York. After her mother died of cancer in 1991, Smith attended Cincinnati Bible College for two years.<ref name=\"ND\">{{cite web|title=Mindy Smith - On the inside|url=http://nodepression.com/article/mindy-smith-inside|website=No Depression|accessdate=26 January 2017|date=31 October 2006}}</ref>\n\nSmith and her father moved to [[Knoxville, Tennessee]], where she began listening to [[folk music|folk]] and [[bluegrass music]], [[Alison Krauss]], and [[the Cox Family]]. In 1998, she moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]] to pursue a career in music. Two years later, she reached the finals of a contest at the [[Kerrville Folk Festival]]. This led to a contract with [http://www.bigyellowdogmusic.com/ Big Yellow Dog Music].<ref name=\"AM bio\">{{cite web|last1=Deming|first1=Mark|title=Mindy Smith {{!}} Biography|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/mindy-smith-mn0000493015/biography|website=AllMusic|accessdate=22 January 2017}}</ref>\n\nSmith attracted attention in 2003 when she sang a cover version of \"[[Jolene (song)|Jolene]]\" by [[Dolly Parton]] for the tribute album\n''[[Just Because I'm a Woman: Songs of Dolly Parton|Just Because I'm a Woman]]''. Soon after, she signed a contract with [[Vanguard Records]], who released her debut album, ''[[One Moment More]]'' in 2004.<ref name=\"AM bio\" /> In addition to Dolly Parton, she has expressed admiration for [[John Prine]], [[Alison Krauss]], [[Patty Griffin]], [[Shania Twain]], [[Kris Kristofferson]], [[Buddy Miller]], and [[Bill Gaither (gospel singer)|Bill Gaither]].<ref name=\"ND\" />\n\n\"Come to Jesus\" was her biggest hit, receiving airplay on [[country music|country]], [[Christian music|Christian]], [[adult album alternative]] (AAA), and [[adult contemporary music|adult contemporary]] radio. The song charted at No. 32 on the [[Adult Top 40]] chart of ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' magazine.{{citation needed|date=January 2017}} In 2004 Smith appeared at the [[Cambridge Folk Festival]] in the U.K., which was broadcast nationally on [[BBC Radio]].\n\nIn October 2006, Smith released \"Out Loud\", the first single from her second album ''[[Long Island Shores]]''. The song was well received by AAA rock radio and Country Music Television ([[CMT (U.S. TV channel)|CMT]]). On January 10, 2007, she performed \"Please Stay\" on ''[[The Tonight Show with Jay Leno]]''.\n\nIn October 2007, Smith released a Christmas album, ''[[My Holiday]]''. She wrote six original songs, including \"I Know the Reason\" with [[Thad Cockrell]].<ref name=\"pop_matters_mindysmith\">{{cite web|url=http://www.popmatters.com/pm/review/mindy-smith-my-holiday/|title=Mindy Smith: My Holiday|last=Gilstrap|first=Andrew|work=[[Popmatters]]|accessdate=2009-10-24}}</ref>\n\nIn August 2009, Smith released her fourth studio album, ''[[Stupid Love (album)|Stupid Love]]''. She appeared on ''[[The Early Show]]'' on August 15, 2009, to perform the first single, \"Highs and Lows\". On September 29, 2009, while promoting the album on the syndicated radio show ''[[World Cafe (radio program)|World Cafe]]'', she disclosed that she had [[obsessive\u2013compulsive disorder]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=113306795|title=Mindy Smith: A Chanteuse's Emotional Return|work=NPR|date=September 29, 2009|accessdate=April 2, 2017}}</ref>\n\nIn June 2012, Smith released an [[Mindy Smith (album)|eponymous independent studio album]] on her own Giant Leap label, in conjunction with TVX. In October of the same year, Vanguard Records released a compilation album of her songs, \"The Essential Mindy Smith\".\n\nOn October 29, 2013, Smith released a holiday EP entitled ''Snowed In'' on Giant Leap/TVX. The release contained both original [[Christmas songs]] and cover material.\n\nBetween 2015 and 2018, Smith contributed (as sole writer or co-writer) several songs to the musical television drama series ''[[Nashville (2012 TV series)|Nashville]]''. She is credited on four of the songs performed by cast members and appearing [[Nashville discography|on the soundtrack]] in the series' final three seasons.\n\n==Charity==\nIn March 2013, Smith worked with [[Anthropologie]] during an in-store performance to raise money and awareness for the [[Captain Planet Foundation]], a non-profit organization. Anthropologie donated fifteen percent of sales made in the first hour after Smith's performance to CPF.<ref name=\"Charity Work\">{{cite web|title=Mindy Smith joins forces with lifestyle brand Anthropologie and Captain Planet|url=http://www.mindysmithmusic.com/news/mindy-smith-joins-forces-lifestyle-brand-anthropologie-and-captain-planet-176|website=Mindy Smith|accessdate=14 October 2015|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924121433/http://www.mindysmithmusic.com/news/mindy-smith-joins-forces-lifestyle-brand-anthropologie-and-captain-planet-176|archivedate=24 September 2015}}</ref>\n\n==Awards and honors==\n* Best New/Emerging Artist of the Year,  [[Americana Music Association]], 2004\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Studio albums===\n\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Bruce_Robison","to":"Bruce Robison"}],"pages":{"10471206":{"pageid":10471206,"ns":0,"title":"Bruce Robison","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n\n{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Bruce Robison\n| image           = Bruce Robison (1).jpg\n| caption         = Robison in 2009\n| birth_name      = Bruce Ben Robison\n| birth_date      = {{Birth date and age|1966|6|11}}\n| origin          = [[Bandera, Texas]]\n| instrument      = Vocals, guitar, harmonica\n| genre           = [[Folk music|Folk]], [[Country music|country]]\n| label           = Vireo, Lucky Dog, Premium\n| spouse = {{Marriage|[[Kelly Willis]]|1996|2022|end=div}}\n| website         = {{url|brucerobison.com}}\n}}\n\n'''Bruce Ben Robison''' (born June 11, 1966) is an American, [[Austin, Texas|Austin]]-based [[Texas country music]] singer-songwriter.  Bruce and his brother, fellow singer-songwriter [[Charlie Robison]], grew up in [[Bandera, Texas]], near [[San Antonio]].  His self-titled debut album was released in 1995.<ref>{{cite web|author=William Ruhlmann |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/bruce-robison-mw0000083869 |title=Bruce Robison \u2013 Bruce Robison &#124; Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |access-date=July 14, 2014}}</ref>\n\nRobison has written several songs which have become hits when covered by well-known singers, including: \"[[Travelin' Soldier]],\" (recorded in 2003 by the [[Dixie Chicks]], reached No. 1 on the Country charts); \"[[Angry All the Time]],\" (recorded by [[Tim McGraw]] and [[Faith Hill]] in 2001, also reached No. 1 on the country charts); and \"[[Wrapped (George Strait song)|Wrapped]]\" (recorded in 2006 by [[George Strait]], reached No. 2 in 2007). Bruce runs The Next Waltz, a record label by artists for artists.\n\n==Personal life==\nSister, Robyn Ludwick, and late brother [[Charlie Robison]] are accomplished singer-songwriters in their own right.\n\nIn 1992, he met singer-songwriter [[Kelly Willis]] and they married in 1996. Together they had a son, Deral Otis, in January 2001. Willis became pregnant again and gave birth to twins Abigail Esme and Benjamin James<ref>[http://www.commotionpr.com/images/BruceKelly_twins.jpg]  {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930095738/http://www.commotionpr.com/images/BruceKelly_twins.jpg |date=September 30, 2007 }}</ref> on March 24, 2003.<ref>{{cite }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://dir.salon.com/story/mwt/feature/2003/08/01/rockermoms/index.html |title=Mothers who rock - Salon.com |publisher=Dir.salon.com |date=August 1, 2003 |access-date=July 14, 2014 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110606191622/http://dir.salon.com/story/mwt/feature/2003/08/01/rockermoms/index.html |archive-date=June 6, 2011 She has recorded thirteen folk albums to date<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cherylwheeler.com/home/discog.html|title=Discography|website=Cherylwheeler.com|access-date=July 2, 2014|archive-date=February 28, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140228181622/http://cherylwheeler.com/home/discog.html|url-status=dead}}</ref> and has toured extensively throughout the United States since the mid-1970s.<ref name=Daley2018>{{Cite news|last=Daley|first=Lauren|title=Cheryl Wheeler follows her bemused muse wherever it takes her|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/arts/music/2018/01/02/cheryl-wheeler-follows-her-bemused-muse-wherever-takes-her/ZFVy1sWqb149tlXHKG7H9M/story.html|work=[[Boston Globe]]|date=January 2, 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=November 28, 2020}}</ref>\n\nHeralded as a \u201cfolk luminary,\u201d an \u201cunassuming folk star,\u201d and a \u201cfolk diva,\u201d Wheeler is known for her well-crafted songs, stellar vocals, and witty on-stage patter.<ref name=Daley2018 /><ref name=DirtyLinen2009>{{Cite web|title=Cheryl Wheeler Launches Record Company, New Record|url=https://dirtylinen.wordpress.com/2009/06/09/cheryl-wheeler-launches-record-company-new-record/|website=Dirty Linen|date=June 9, 2009|access-date=November 28, 2020}}</ref><ref name=Hill2007>{{Cite news|last=Hill|first=Whit|title=Cheryl Wheeler - Hero, worshipped|url=https://annarborobserver.com/articles/cheryl_wheeler_full_article.html|work=[[Ann Arbor Observer]]|date=April 2007|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201207210408/https://annarborobserver.com/articles/cheryl_wheeler_full_article.html|archive-date=December 7, 2020|access-date=November 28, 2020|url-status=dead}}</ref> ''The Boston Globe'' wrote: \u201cOver decades, she\u2019s built a cult following through Boston radio and the New England folk circuit for her uncanny ability, not unlike Tom Rush, to have her audience laughing during one song and silently tearing up with the next.\u201d<ref name=Daley2018 /> \u201cIf Wheeler never picked up an instrument, she could have easily become a comedian,\u201d said another reviewer. \u201cFortunately for us, she does both. Because, after the jokes, stories and self-deprecating comments have people rolling in the aisles, she starts singing and her voice is spellbinding.\u201d<ref name=Nostrand2016>{{Cite news|last=Nostrand|first=George V.|title=Cheryl Wheeler: Comic, storyteller, poet, singer-songwriter|url=https://www.rutlandherald.com/cheryl-wheeler-comic-storyteller-poet-singer-songwriter/article_dd926171-cb69-5f3e-a389-69d733b2c2a1.html|work=[[Rutland Herald]]|date=March 24, 2016|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=November 28, 2020}}</ref>\n\n== Early life ==\nBorn and raised in [[Timonium, Maryland]], Wheeler began playing ukulele and guitar in middle school and writing songs in high school, making up melodies to go with the poems in \u201cThe Golden Book of Poetry,\u201d a children's book.<ref name=Daley2018 /><ref name=McNally2017>{{Cite web|last=McNally|first=Owen|title=Folk Singer Cheryl Wheeler Brings Her Saucy Stage Persona To Iron Horse|url=https://www.courant.com/ctnow/music/hc-cheryl-wheeler-at-iron-horse-20170109-story.html|work=[[Hartford Courant]]|date=January 9, 2017|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201208231538/https://www.courant.com/ctnow/music/hc-cheryl-wheeler-at-iron-horse-20170109-story.html |archive-date=December 8, 2020 |access-date=November 28, 2020}}</ref><ref name=Lenker>{{Cite news|last=Lenker|first=George|title=Cheryl Wheeler talks songwriting, humor, before Northampton shows|url=https://www.masslive.com/entertainment/2019/01/cheryl_wheeler_talks_songwriti.html|work=[[The Republican (Springfield, Massachusetts)|MassLive]]|date=January 1, 2019|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=November 28, 2020}}</ref> Wheeler completed two years of community college and then transferred to [[Coker College]] in South Carolina. She quit in early 1972. \u201cI didn\u2019t quit thinking: Do I embark on a folk music career?\u201d she said. \u201cI quit because I was in 15th grade, and enough was enough already.\u201d<ref name=Daley2018 />\n\nNot long after leaving college, Wheeler was hired at a steakhouse as a waitress. \u201cWithin a week, the owners and me, we realized we made a terrible mistake,\u201d she said. \u201cI could never be a waitress. But they needed [a musician], and I thought maybe I could do that, and they were relieved to get me out of waitressing.\"<ref name=Daley2018 /> Around the same time, Wheeler began performing at clubs in the [[Washington, D.C.]], and [[Baltimore]] area.<ref name=Bellaire2015>{{Cite web|last1=Bellaire|first1=Rick|title=Cheryl Wheeler|url=http://www.ripopmusic.org/musical-artists/musicians/cheryl-wheeler/|website=Rhode Island Music Hall of Fame Historical Archive|date=April 2015|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131025083307/http://www.ripopmusic.org:80/musical-artists/musicians/cheryl-wheeler/ |archive-date=October 25, 2013 |access-date=November 28, 2020}}</ref>\n\n== Career ==\nIn 1976, Wheeler moved to [[Providence, Rhode Island]], and began playing at folk clubs throughout New England, opening for artists such as [[Jonathan Edwards (musician)|Jonathan Edwards]], [[Tom Rush]], [[Jesse Winchester]], and [[Gordon Lightfoot]].<ref name=Lenker /><ref name=Bellaire2015 /><ref name=Whitlock1996>{{Cite news|last=Whitlock|first=Jennifer|title=Several Singers Have Scored with Cheryl Wheeler Songs|url=https://www.mcall.com/news/mc-xpm-1996-01-19-3082110-story.html|work=[[The Morning Call]]|date=January 19, 1996|url-status=|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=November 28, 2020}}{{deadlink|date=September 2023}}</ref> Her big break came when Edwards asked her to audition for a spot in his band as a bass player. Wheeler didn't play bass, but she bought one and auditioned nonetheless. \u201cTo my complete astonishment, I got the gig,\" Wheeler recalled. \"But I knew I didn't get it for my bass playing. So I thought I must've got it for my singing. So that was a real shot in the arm because I hadn't thought about it before, but I thought I might actually be a good singer if Jonathan Edwards is hiring me.\"<ref name=Lenker />\n\nIn 1983, Wheeler released her first album, a four-song EP called ''Newport Songs'', which is now out of print. Her next two releases \u2013 a self-titled album in 1986 and ''Half a Book'' in 1987 \u2013 were produced by North Star Records in Providence. The song \u201cAddicted,\u201d from the self-titled album, was recorded by country singer [[Dan Seals]] and became a No. 1 hit for him in 1988 on Billboard's Top 40 Country chart.<ref name=Bellaire2015 />\n\nFollowing the success of her first two full-length albums, Wheeler was signed to [[Capitol Records]] and released ''Circles and Arrows'' in 1990. [[Suzy Bogguss]] recorded Wheeler's song \u201cAces\u201d from this album, and it reached #9 on the country charts in 1992. Wheeler's next four albums \u2013 ''Driving Home'' (1993), ''Mrs. Pinocci's Guitar'' (1995), ''Sylvia Hotel'' (1999), and ''Defying Gravity'' (2005) \u2013 were produced by the folk-oriented Philo-Rounder Records in Cambridge, Massachusetts.<ref name=Bellaire2015 />\n\nIn 2003, Wheeler approved the production of a double disc album, ''No Previous Record'',<ref>{{Cite web|title=No Previous Record|url=http://cherylwheeler.com/discog/npr.html|website=Cherylwheeler.com|access-date=October 3, 2006|archive-date=October 12, 2006|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061012134701/http://www.cherylwheeler.com/discog/npr.html|url-status=dead}}</ref> which contains songs that never made it onto a commercial recording. Distribution of the album is free, but restricted to members of her e-mail list.{{citation needed|date=November 2020}}\n\nWheeler's two most-recent albums \u2013 ''Pointing at the Sun'' (2009) and ''Cheryl Wheeler Live'' (2012) \u2013 were released by her own record label, Dias Records.<ref name=DirtyLinen2009 /><ref name=Bellaire2015 />\n\nWheeler's songs have been covered by a number of other artists in addition to [[Dan Seals]] and [[Suzy Bogguss]]. They include [[Kathy Mattea]], [[Sylvia Kirby|Sylvia]], [[Garth Brooks]], [[Peter, Paul, and Mary]], [[Bette Midler]], [[Kenny Loggins]], [[Melanie Safka|Melanie]], [[Holly Near]], and D.C. Anderson.<ref name=Bellaire2015 /><ref name=DirtyLinen2009 /> Wheeler has said she doesn't purposefully write for other people, but she appreciates when others cover her songs. \u201c[It\u2019s] great. I make money if they do well,\u201d she said. \u201cBut more than that, it's wonderful to have a singer you respect singing your song.\"<ref name=Whitlock1996 />\n\nHer song \"If It Were Up to Me\" (which was written shortly after the [[1998 Westside Middle School shooting]]), with the closing line \"If it were up to me, I'd take away the guns\" got nationwide attention shortly after the [[Columbine High School massacre]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=If It Were Up to Me|url=http://cherylwheeler.com/songs/iiwutm.html|website=Cherylwheeler.com|access-date=April 15, 2020|archive-date=October 20, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101020161720/http://cherylwheeler.com/songs/iiwutm.html|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref name=DirtyLinen2009 /> Wheeler released the recording into the public domain to exempt radio stations from paying royalties (it was being played every hour near the high school), and Rounder Records ran a promotional campaign to donate money to the [[Brady Campaign]] each time the song was played on [[Adult Album Alternative]] radio stations.{{citation needed|date=November 2020}}\n\nIn 2014, Wheeler was inducted into the Rhode Island Music Hall of Fame.<ref name=Bellaire2015 />\n\n==Performances==\nWheeler has toured extensively throughout her career, and her live concerts include both comedic and serious commentary in addition to the songs themselves. As one reviewer wrote, she \u201cmasterfully blends blisteringly on-target observational humor, simple storytelling, gorgeous guitar work, and beautiful, rich songs.\u201d<ref name=Hill2007 /> Another commented on her \u201cfree-wheeling live concerts\u201d and called Wheeler a \u201cthoughtful, amusing musician and storyteller (and irrepressible social critic)\u2026. [H]er patter is a delicious, folk-flavored blend of Phyllis Diller and Mort Sahl, sometimes puckish, sometimes barbed.\u201d<ref name=McNally2017 />\n\nAbout half of the songs Wheeler performs in concert are not available on any of her albums.<ref name=Nostrand2016 /> Many never get recorded and eventually fade from her set list. Although she mostly tours alone, she has also toured with [[Kenny White]] (who produced a number of her albums). White generally opens for her and then plays and sings harmony during Wheeler's set.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://cherylwheeler.com/home/promoconfig.html|title=Performance Configurations|website=Cherylwheeler.com|access-date=July 3, 2009|archive-date=June 19, 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090619105334/http://www.cherylwheeler.com/home/promoconfig.html|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref name=McNally2017 /> Wheeler has also toured with the [[Christine Lavin]]-inspired tour \"On a Winter's Night\" and occasionally as part of Lavin's consortium [[Four Bitchin' Babes]].<ref name=Nostrand2016 />\n\nWheeler participated in a concert with fellow folk singer-songwriters [[Shawn Colvin]] and [[Mary Chapin Carpenter]] in 1988, the year before Colvin released her debut album.<ref name=Nostrand2016 /> The three performed on two consecutive nights, to critical acclaim, at [[The Birchmere]] in [[Alexandria, Virginia]]. The two performances were recorded at the soundboard and although never released officially, have been favorites among fans of the three artists.{{citation needed|date=November 2020}}\n\n== Personal life ==\nWheeler is openly [[lesbian]].<ref name=Advocate1999>{{cite magazine|title=Wheeler's angry anthem |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iWMEAAAAMBAJ&dq=Wheeler&pg=PA79 |magazine=[[The Advocate (LGBT magazine)|The Advocate]] |date=June 8, 1999 |page=22 |access-date=25 January 2022}}</ref> She and her wife, Cathleen, live in Swansea, Massachusetts.<ref name=Daley2018 /> They were married in 2004, ten days after Massachusetts made [[same-sex marriage]] legal.<ref name=TGV2013>{{Cite news|title=Think, laugh and cry: An interview with Cheryl Wheeler|url=https://thegavoice.com/culture/music/think-laugh-and-cry-an-interview-with-cheryl-wheeler/|work=[[The Georgia Voice]]|date=October 25, 2013|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=November 28, 2020}}</ref><ref name=Daley2018 />\n\nIn October 2022, her management announced that her forthcoming concerts were cancelled due to hospitalization for mental health challenges.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://meandthee.org/concerts/cheryl-wheeler-oct2022/|title=Cheryl Wheeler [canceled] at the me&thee coffeehouse 7 October 2022 {{!}} Kenny White Special Guest|date=October 7, 2022|website=Me & Thee Music}}</ref>\n\nShe returned to performing in 2023.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pfmsconcerts.org/concert/debs/cheryl-wheeler-kenny-white-101523|title=Cheryl Wheeler with Kenny White - 10/15/23|website=Peterborough Folk Music Society}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/2024/04/23/arts/cheryl-wheeler/|title=Singer-songwriter Cheryl Wheeler talks about returning to performing after being in rehab|first=Noah|last=Schaffer|date=April 23, 2024|newspaper=[[The Boston Globe]]}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\nMost of the following albums are still in print:\n\n===Studio albums===\n* ''Cheryl Wheeler'' (1985)\n* ''Half a Book'' (1987)\n* ''Circles and Arrows'' (1990)\n* ''Driving Home'' (1993)\n* ''Mrs. Pinocci's Guitar'' (1995)\n* ''Sylvia Hotel'' (1999)\n* ''Defying Gravity'' (2005)\n* ''Pointing at the Sun'' (2009)\n* ''Greetings: Cheryl Wheeler Live (feat. Kenny White) (2012)\n\n===EPs===\n* ''Newport Songs'' (1983)\n* ''Live and Otherwise'' (1987)\n\n===Compilation albums===\n* ''Different Stripe'' (2000)\n* ''No Previous Record'' (2003)\n\n===Other contributions===\n*''[[Live at the World Caf\u00e9 - Volume 9]]'' (1999) \u2013 \"If It Were Up to Me\"\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n*[http://www.CherylWheeler.com Official website]\n*[http://www.mmreview.com/ronsfolkchords Cheryl Wheeler guitar chords]\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Wheeler, Cheryl}}\n[[Category:1951 births]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:20th-century American guitarists]]\n[[Category:20th-century American singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:20th-century American women guitarists]]\n[[Category:20th-century American women singers]]\n[[Category:20th-century American LGBTQ people]]\n[[Category:21st-century American guitarists]]\n[[Category:21st-century American singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:21st-century American women guitarists]]\n[[Category:21st-century American women singers]]\n[[Category:21st-century American LGBTQ people]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American folk musicians]]\n[[Category:American lesbian musicians]]\n[[Category:American women country singers]]\n[[Category:Fast Folk artists]]\n[[Category:LGBTQ people from Maryland]]\n[[Category:People from Timonium, Maryland]]\n[[Category:People from Swansea, Massachusetts]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Maryland]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Michael_Johnson_(singer)","to":"Michael Johnson (singer)"}],"pages":{"569909":{"pageid":569909,"ns":0,"title":"Michael Johnson (singer)","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American musician and singer (1944\u20132017)}}\n{{Other people|Michael Johnson|Michael Johnson (disambiguation){{!}}Michael Johnson}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=July 2014}} \n{{Infobox musical artist\n| image             = MichaelJohnson2001.jpg\n| image_size        = \n| name              = Michael Johnson\n| caption           = Johnson in 2002\n| background        = solo_singer\n| birth_name        = Michael Jay Johnson\n| birth_date        = {{Birth date|1944|8|8}}\n| birth_place       = [[Alamosa, Colorado]], U.S.\n| death_date        = {{death date and age|2017|7|25|1944|8|8}}\n| death_place       = [[Minneapolis|Minneapolis, Minnesota]], U.S.\n| instrument        = Vocals, classical guitar, acoustic guitar, piano\n| genre             = [[Folk music|Folk]],<ref name=\"auto\">{{Cite web|url=https://ricochet.com/444725/archives/michael-johnson-1944-2017-a-requiem/|title=Michael Johnson (1944-2017): A Requiem|website=Ricochet|date=July 28, 2017 }}</ref> [[folk rock]], [[country music|country]],<ref name=\"auto\"/> [[soft rock]]<ref name=\"auto\"/>\n| occupation        = Singer-songwriter, instrumentalist, [[recording industry|record producer]], actor, writer\n| years_active      = 1957\u20132017\n| label             = [[Atco Records|Atco]], Sanskrit Records, [[EMI]], [[RCA]], [[Vanguard Records|Vanguard]], [[Atlantic Records|Atlantic]], Intersound, American Originals, [[Red House Records|Red House]]\n| website           = {{URL|http://www.mjblue.com}}\n}}\n\n'''Michael Jay Johnson''' (August 8, 1944 \u2013 July 25, 2017) was an American pop, [[country music|country]], and [[folk music|folk]] singer-songwriter and guitarist. He is best remembered for his 1978 hit song \"[[Bluer Than Blue]]\". He charted four hits on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] chart and nine more on [[Hot Country Songs]], including two number one country hits in 1986's \"[[Give Me Wings]]\" and \"[[The Moon Is Still Over Her Shoulder]]\". He also co-wrote \"Cain's Blood\", the debut single of 1990s country group [[4 Runner]].\n\n==Career==\n{{more citations needed|section|date=July 2017}}\nJohnson was born in the small town of [[Alamosa, Colorado]] and grew up in [[Denver]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.mjblue.com/|title=Michael Johnson: Singer & Guitarist|website=Mjblue.com|access-date=August 7, 2021}}</ref> He started playing the guitar at 13. In 1963, he began attending Colorado State College (now the [[University of Northern Colorado]]) in Greeley to study music but his college career was truncated when he won an international talent contest two years later. First prize included a deal with [[Epic Records]].<ref>{{cite magazine |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/country/news/bluer-than-blue-singer-michael-johnson-dead-at-72-w492020|title='Bluer Than Blue' Singer Michael Johnson Dead at 72|first=Stephen L.|last=Betts|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=July 27, 2017|issn=0035-791X}}</ref>\n\nWishing to hone his instrumental skills, in 1966 he set off for [[Barcelona, Spain]], to the [[Liceu Conservatory]], studying with the eminent classical guitarists, Graciano Tarrag\u00f3 and [[Renata Tarrag\u00f3]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mjblue.com/bcountry.html|author=Barry McCloud|title=''Definitive Country: The Ultimate Encyclopedia of Country Music and Its Performers'' (Perige, 1995).}}</ref> Upon his return to the States, he joined [[Randy Sparks]] in a group called the New Society and did a tour of the Orient.\n\nWhen the band dissolved in 1967, he signed on with the [[Chad Mitchell Trio]] for a year, spending some of that time co-writing with another member, [[John Denver]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://chadmitchelltrio.com/|title=Chad Mitchell Trio - Official Website|website=Chadmitchelltrio.com|access-date=August 7, 2021}}</ref> The group was renamed Denver, Boise & Johnson. When the trio came to an end, Johnson made a radical departure from everything he had done previously by taking on a major supporting role in the off-Broadway production of ''[[Jacques Brel Is Alive and Well and Living in Paris]].''<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/obituary/7881194/bluer-than-blue-michael-johnson-obit |title='Bluer Than Blue' Singer Michael Johnson Dies at 72 |first=Chuck |last=Dauphin |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=July 27, 2017 |issn=0006-2510}}</ref>\n\nIn 1971, Johnson signed with [[Atco Records]] to record his first album, ''There Is A Breeze'', which was released in 1973 and produced by Johnson, Chris Dedrick, [[Peter Yarrow]] and [[Phil Ramone]] in New York and Toronto, Canada.<ref name=\"LarkinCountry\">{{cite book|title=[[Encyclopedia of Popular Music|The Guinness Who's Who of Country Music]]|editor=[[Colin Larkin (writer)|Colin Larkin]]|publisher=[[Guinness Publishing]]|date=1993|edition=First|isbn=0-85112-726-6|pages=206/8}}</ref> Feeling this first effort was not a true reflection of his music (despite being a best seller in the Minneapolis-St. Paul area), Johnson self-produced his next LP in 1975, ''For All You Mad Musicians'', relying more on his voice and guitar for a folk feel. He followed this up with ''Ain't Dis Da Life'', where he added a rhythm section. With each new recording and his continued touring, his popularity was increasing.\n\nTeaming up with [[Brent Maher]] and Steve Gibson in [[Nashville, Tennessee]], Johnson created a two-song demo consisting of \"[[Bluer Than Blue]]\" and \"[[Almost Like Being in Love]]\" (the latter song from the Broadway musical ''[[Brigadoon (musical)|Brigadoon]]''). [[EMI America]] took one listen and wasted no time in signing him, quickly getting ''The Michael Johnson Album'' out in 1978. \"Bluer Than Blue\" was written by Randy Goodrum. The first single, \"Bluer Than Blue\", became Johnson's first [[Top 40]] hit, peaking at No.&nbsp;12 on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] chart in the summer of 1978;<ref name=\"LarkinCountry\"/> the song became a chart-topping single on the [[Hot Adult Contemporary Tracks|Adult Contemporary]] chart. \"Almost Like Being in Love\" went to No.&nbsp;91 on the [[Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs|R&B]] chart while hitting the Top 5 on the AC chart and the Top 40 on the pop chart. \n\nJohnson recorded five albums in all for EMI and in 1985 moved over to [[RCA Records]],<ref name=\"LarkinCountry\"/> where he adopted a contemporary country style that stayed compatible with his soft, mellow leanings. He scored five Top Ten country hits from 1986 to 1989, including the chart-toppers \"Give Me Wings\" and \"The Moon Is Still Over Her Shoulder.\"<ref name=\"LarkinCountry\"/> After two country albums on RCA (plus two greatest hits collections), Johnson moved over to [[Atlantic Records]] in 1991.\n\nIn 1995, the country music group [[4 Runner]] scored a minor hit with the single \"[[Cain's Blood]]\", for which Johnson co-wrote an updated version with Jack Sundrud of [[Poco (band)|Poco]].\n\n==Death==\nJohnson died at his home in [[Minneapolis|Minneapolis, Minnesota]] on July 25, 2017, two weeks before what would have been his 73rd birthday.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.startribune.com/bluer-than-blue-singer-michael-johnson-dies-at-72/436868903|title='Bluer Than Blue' Singer Michael Johnson dies at 72|first=Jon|last=Bream|newspaper=[[Star Tribune]]|date=July 27, 2017}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n! rowspan=\"2\"|Year\n! Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Darden_Smith","to":"Darden Smith"}],"pages":{"38859823":{"pageid":38859823,"ns":0,"title":"Darden Smith","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n\n{{autobiography|date=October 2019}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name         = Darden Smith\n| image        = Darden Smith, Matt Sturtevant.jpeg\n| image_size   =\n| caption      = Smith in 2013\n| birth_name   = Darden Craig Smith\n| birth_date   = {{birth date and age|mf=yes|1962|03|11}}\n| origin       = [[Austin, TX|Austin]], [[Texas]] [[United States|US]]\n| instrument   = [[Guitar]]\n| genre        = [[Folk music|Folk]], [[Americana (music)|Americana]], [[Rock music|Rock]], [[Country music|Country]]\n| occupation   = Singer-songwriter, educator\n| years_active = 1986\u2013present\n| label        = [[Compass Records]], [[Dualtone Music Group]], DardenMusic, [[Columbia Music]], [[Ensign Records]]\n| website      = {{URL|http://www.dardensmith.com}}\n}}\n'''Darden Smith''' (born March 11, 1962, in [[Brenham, Texas]]) is an [[Austin, Texas|Austin]]-based singer-songwriter known for his lyrics and for weaving [[Folk music|folk]] and [[Americana (music)|Americana]] influences with [[Rock music|rock]], [[Pop music|pop]], and the musical roots of his home state.<ref name=\"Quick Change Artist\">Keith Kachtick, \"Quick Change Artist ''Texas Monthly'' p. 70 (October 3, 1996).</ref> His debut album, \"Native Soil,\" was released in 1986. His sixteenth album, ''Western Skies,'' was released March 25, 2022.<ref name=\"Darden Smith Hears Love Calling\">{{Cite web | title=Darden Smith Hears Love Calling on August 27th Album | url=http://www.directcurrentmusic.com/dc-music-news-feed/2013/4/11/darden-smith-hears-love-calling-on-august-27-album-stream-an.html | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130416213737/http://www.directcurrentmusic.com/dc-music-news-feed/2013/4/11/darden-smith-hears-love-calling-on-august-27-album-stream-an.html | archive-date=2013-04-16 }} ''Direct Current Music'' (April 11, 2013). Accessed May 1, 2013.</ref> Smith has published two books, ''The Habit of Noticing: Using Creativity to Make a Life (and a Living) (''2018) and ''Western Skies (2022),'' a companion book for the album of the same name. Over the past two decades, Smith has developed two non-profit programs, The Be An Artist Program (2003)<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite web |title=Darden Smith Songwriting Workshop |url=https://www.marfalivearts.org/darden-smith-songwriting-workshop |access-date=2022-10-12 |website=marfalivearts |language=en}}</ref> and SongwritingWith: Soldiers (2011).<ref name=\":1\">{{Cite web |title=Songwriting With Soldiers |url=https://www.songwritingwithsoldiers.org/ |access-date=2022-10-12 |language=en-US}}</ref> Both use collaborative songwriting to work with groups ranging from children in the classroom to military members returning home from combat.<ref name=\"Music Row\">{{Cite web | author=Jessica Nicholson | title=Nashville Songwriters Partner With SongwritingWith:Soldiers | url=http://www.musicrow.com/2013/04/nashville-songwriters-partner-with-songwritingwithsoldiers/ | publisher=Music Row | date=2013-04-09}}</ref> Smith established SongwritingWith:Soldiers as a separate non-profit organization in 2012.<ref name=\"Writing Songs Provides Peace for Some Soldiers\">{{Cite news |last=Shevory |first=Kristina |date=2012-11-17 |title=Writing Songs Provides Peace for Some Soldiers |language=en-US |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/11/18/us/songwritingwithsoldiers-eases-way-for-soldiers.html |access-date=2023-02-17 |issn=0362-4331}}</ref>\n\n== Biography ==\nSmith's early interest in music was sparked by singing in the local church choir, the \"seat-rattling sound\" of the church's [[pipe organ]], and accompanying his parents to [[country-western dance]]s. By the third grade, he had a [[guitar]] and a teacher who taught him how to play every song on [[Neil Young]]'s ''[[Harvest (Neil Young album)|Harvest]]'' and ''[[After the Gold Rush]]''. Smith began writing his own songs at age ten. In 1976, after his family moved to [[Humble, Texas]], in the [[Houston]] suburbs, Smith spent his teen years listening to [[Guy Clark]], [[Townes Van Zandt]], [[John Prine]], and [[Bob Dylan]].<ref name=\"Quick Change Artist\"/> His musical influences expanded when he moved to Austin to attend [[The University of Texas]] and was exposed to [[blues]] and [[reggae]], as well as musicians coming out of the [[United Kingdom]] such as [[Nick Lowe]], [[Elvis Costello]], and [[The Pretenders]].<ref>{{Cite web | title=Darden Smith: Biography | url=http://www.last.fm/music/Darden+Smith/+wiki | website=Last FM }}</ref> Smith quickly got involved with Austin's burgeoning music scene, playing in small Austin venues like the Alamo Lounge, Taco Flats, and Waterloo Ice House. By the time Smith graduated with a [[Bachelor of Arts]] in American Studies (1985),<ref>{{Cite web |title=College of Liberal Arts {{!}} The University of Texas at Austin |url=https://liberalarts.utexas.edu/ |access-date=2022-10-12 |website=liberalarts.utexas.edu |language=en}}</ref> he was a regular on the local and Texas music scenes.<ref name=\"Quick Change Artist\"/> He has one son and one daughter.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.thebluegrasssituation.com/read/conversations-darden-smith |title=Conversations With... Darden Smith &#124; the Bluegrass Situation |access-date=2015-06-18 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150618214412/http://www.thebluegrasssituation.com/read/conversations-darden-smith |archive-date=2015-06-18 |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n\n== Career ==\n\n[[File:Darden Smith Performing.jpeg|thumb|350px|left|Photograph by Stacy L. Pearsall]]\nAfter releasing ''Native Soil'' in 1986,<ref>{{Citation |title=Darden Smith - Native Soil |date=1986 |url=https://www.discogs.com/release/6632826-Darden-Smith-Native-Soil |language=en |access-date=2022-10-12}}</ref> Darden Smith was signed by [[Dick James Music]] to a publishing deal. In 1987, [[Epic Records]] signed Smith at the inaugural [[South by Southwest Festival]] and released ''Darden Smith'' (1988), which produced two country chart hit singles, \u201cLittle Maggie\u201d and \u201cDay After Tomorrow.\u201d<ref>{{Cite web | author=Johnny Loftus | title=Darden Smith Biography | url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/darden-smith-mn0000572385  | publisher=AllMusic}}</ref> Later that year, [[Nigel Grainge]], the head of [[Ensign Records]], introduced Smith to the British songwriter [[Boo Hewerdine]]. Four days later, they had eight songs and a record deal with Ensign/Chrysalis that resulted in ''Evidence'' (1989). After Smith's label deal with Epic was transferred to the pop division of [[Columbia Records]], he released ''[[Trouble No More (Darden Smith album)|Trouble No More]]'' (1990), best known for \u201cMidnight Train\u201d and \u201cFrankie & Sue,\" and ''[[Little Victories (Darden Smith album)|Little Victories]]'' (1993) which included the Top 10 pop hit single, \"Loving Arms\".<ref name=\"Quick Change Artist\"/>\n\nSmith left Columbia in 1995 and spent several years without an agent or label. He returned to recording through independent labels, which led to ''Deep Fantastic Blue'',<ref>{{Cite web |first=Keith |last=Kachtick |date=1996-10-01 |title=Quick-Change Artist |url=https://www.texasmonthly.com/arts-entertainment/quick-change-artist/ |access-date=2022-10-12 |website=Texas Monthly |language=en}}</ref> on Plump Records,<ref>{{Cite web |title=Plump Records |url=https://www.discogs.com/label/24030-Plump-Records |access-date=2022-10-12 |website=Discogs |language=en}}</ref> and a trio of albums for [[Dualtone Records]]\u00a0(''Sunflower'', 2002; ''Circo'', 2004; ''Field of Crows'', 2005).<ref name=\"Marathon\">{{Cite web | author=Jim Caligiuri | title=Darden Smith - For the Sake of the Song | url=http://www.austinchronicle.com/music/2010-11-26/darden-smith-marathon/ }}</ref> He self- released a collection of his favorites from his previous albums, ''After All This Time'',<ref>{{Cite web |last=Armstrong |first=Gene |title=Darden Smith: After All This Time: The Best of Darden Smith (Darden Music) |url=https://www.tucsonweekly.com/tucson/darden-smith-after-all-this-time-the-best-of-darden-smith-darden-music/Content?oid=1816547 |access-date=2022-10-12 |website=Tucson Weekly |language=en}}</ref> in 2007, to ''Marathon''<ref>{{Cite web |last=Caligiuri |first=Jim |date=November 26, 2010 |title=Darden Smith: Marathon Album Review |url=https://www.austinchronicle.com/music/2010-11-26/darden-smith-marathon/ |access-date=2022-10-12 |website=www.austinchronicle.com |language=en-US}}</ref> (2010), a 15-track cycle of songs named for a remote town in West Texas, described by one reviewer as \"a peak in [Smith's] 25-year songwriting career.<ref>{{Cite web | author=Patrick Beach | title=Lesson in Passion | url=http://www.statesman.com/news/entertainment/music/lesson-in-passion-austin-singer-songwriter-darde-2/nRbdp/ | archive-url=https://archive.today/20130630093304/http://www.statesman.com/news/entertainment/music/lesson-in-passion-austin-singer-songwriter-darde-2/nRbdp/ |archive-date=2013-06-30 }}</ref> His 2017 album ''Everything''<ref>{{Cite web |last=Hernandez |first=Raoul |date=April 14, 2017 |title=Darden Smith: Everything Album Review |url=https://www.austinchronicle.com/music/2017-04-14/darden-smith-everything/ |access-date=2022-10-12 |website=www.austinchronicle.com |language=en-US}}</ref> was co-produced by Smith and [[Stewart Lerman]] and released on [[Compass Records]]. ''The Habit of Noticing:Using Creativity to Make a Life (and a Living)'' (2018) was published by Irie Books.<ref>{{Cite web |title=The Habit of Noticing |url=https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/41718670-the-habit-of-noticing |access-date=2022-10-12 |website=www.goodreads.com}}</ref> ''Western Skies'' (2022) is multi-media work comprising a new studio record, a book of photography, lyrics, and essays. A spoken word album, ''Western Skies - The Essays'' (2022) was released in 2022.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Shannon |first=Hannah Means |date=2022-03-28 |title=Interview: Darden Smith Takes The Time To Discover 'Western Skies' \u2022 Americana Highways |url=https://americanahighways.org/2022/03/28/interview-darden-smith-takes-the-time-to-discover-western-skies/ |access-date=2022-10-12 |website=Americana Highways |language=en-US}}</ref> Smith continues to write songs for his own albums as well as collaborating with other writers on outside projects. He tours regularly, performing at venues across America and the UK.\n\n== Visual Art ==\nSmith began drawing in his late twenties as a way to remain creative while traveling for music. What began a private exercise now makes up a major part of his work. His first gallery show was at Austin\u2019s Bale Creek Allen Gallery (2018).<ref>{{Cite web |title=Bale Creek Allen Gallery |url=http://balecreekallengallery.com/ |access-date=2022-10-12 |website=Bale Creek Allen Gallery |language=en-US}}</ref> His work is in corporate and private collections in the US, UK and Europe. ''The Western Skies \u2013 Lithographs'' series premiered at Houston\u2019s Redbud Gallery in March 2022.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Darden Smith {{!}} Redbud Gallery {{!}} Houston |url=https://www.redbudgallery.com/darden-smith |access-date=2022-10-12 |website=redbud-gallery |language=en}}</ref> ''Lucky Strikes'', an etching from 2018, was purchased by the Library of Congress for the Prints and Photography Collection.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Library of Congress Acquisitions |url=https://www.flatbedpress.com/library-of-congress-acquisitions |access-date=2022-10-12 |website=Flatbed Press |language=en-US}}</ref>\n\n== Collaborative Songwriting ==\nSmith began writing songs with non-songwriters in 2003 with Smith founded The Be An Artist Program in 2003.<ref name=\":0\" /> The program bringing arts and creativity into educational settings, including songwriting with students. Smith has brought this work to such diverse groups as homeless young adults at [[Covenant House]] in [[New Jersey]]; residents of [[South Africa]] and [[Sefhare]], [[Botswana]] suffering from [[HIV/AIDS]], and Israeli and Palestinian groups. He co-founded SongwritingWith:Soldiers in 2012 with Mary Judd to bring professional songwriters together with military members and their families to process the effects of combat and the return home.<ref name=\":1\" /> In 2021 he co-founded Frontline Songs to bring this therapeutic process to frontline healthcare workers during the pandemic. Through his Collaborative Songwriting, he works with corporate clients and individuals to use songwriting in corporate settings to help tell stories through song, and to foster greater understanding.\n\n== Other contributions ==\n\n* Songwriter-in-Residence at [[University of Texas at Austin]]'s College of Fine Arts<ref>{{cite web | url=https://news.utexas.edu/2023/09/07/ut-names-darden-smith-its-inaugural-texas-songwriter-in-residence/ | title=UT Names Darden Smith its Inaugural Texas Songwriter in Residence | date=7 September 2023 }}</ref>\n* Artist-in-Residence at [[Oklahoma State University]]\u2019s Institute for Creativity and Innovation<ref>{{cite web|title=Institute for Creativity and Innovation| url= http://creativity.okstate.edu/speakerseries/past-speakerseries/ |date=October 7, 2011}}{{dead link|date=June 2024}}</ref>\n* Arts Entrepreneur-in-Residence at Oklahoma's School of Entrepreneurship.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://entrepreneurship.okstate.edu/ses/cie/ |title=Creativity, Innovation, and Entrepreneurship Scholars Program |access-date=2013-04-06 |archive-date=2013-07-16 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130716055202/http://entrepreneurship.okstate.edu/ses/cie/ |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n* Published \"Using Your Gift: Creativity in the Classroom\" with [[The Huffington Post]].<ref>{{Cite web | title=Darden Smith: Using Your Gift: Creativity in the College Classroom | url=http://lifestyle.topnewstoday.org/lifestyle/article/5323392/ | archive-url=https://archive.today/20130705172217/http://lifestyle.topnewstoday.org/lifestyle/article/5323392/ | archive-date=2013-07-05 | publisher=Top News Today}}</ref>\n* Developed scripts and workshop performances of \u201cMarathon\u201d (2009\u201310).<ref name=\"Marathon\"/>\n* Researched and produced \u201cSongs From the Big Sky,\u201d a radio documentary on Texas songwriters for [[BBC Radio 2]] (2006).<ref>{{Cite web |title=BBC - Music - South By South West |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/music/southbysouthwest/radio2/schedule.shtml |access-date=2023-02-17 |website=www.bbc.co.uk}}</ref>\n* Composed \u201cGrand Motion,\u201d a symphony commissioned by [[Peter Bay]] for the [[Austin Symphony Orchestra]], accompanied by dance performance inspired by composition (1999).<ref name=\"Singer takes symphony in new direction\">Jerry Young, \"Singer takes symphony in new direction,\" ''Austin American-Statesman,'' (November 4, 1999).</ref>\n* Composed music for dance/theatre productions, including \u201c9 Chains to the Moon\u201d and \u201cWalking on Water\u201d for the Johnson/Long Dance Company in Austin, TX (1988\u201394).<ref name=\"Singer takes symphony in new direction\"/>\n\n==Discography==\n\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n!
