\u2014\n|-\n| \"Easy\" <small>(featuring Michele Rodgers)</small>\n| align=\"center\"| flip\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n|}\n\n==Films==\nRodgers parlayed his singing fame into a brief movie career with lead performances in:\n* ''[[The Little Shepherd of Kingdom Come (1961 film)|The Little Shepherd of Kingdom Come]]'' (1961)\n* ''[[Back Door to Hell]]'' (1964)\nJimmie sang the song titled \"Half Sung Song\" in the 1977 comedy film ''[[The Billion Dollar Hobo]]'', starring [[Tim Conway]].\n\n==Television==\nTV appearances included performances on ''[[American Bandstand]]'', ''[[Kraft Music Hall]]'', and ''[[Hootenanny]]'', as well as the following:\n* ''[[Hee Haw]]''&nbsp;\u2014 Himself (2 episodes, November 25, 1979 and November 3, 1980)\n* ''[[The George Burns Show]]''&nbsp;\u2014 Himself; Jimmie Rodgers Moves in with Ronnie (1 episode, March 3, 1959). When Jimmie Rodgers moves in with Ronnie, the apartment is suddenly overrun with pretty young groupies, so a jealous Judi turns to George for help.<ref>The George Burns Show; Wikipedia</ref>\n* ''[[The Mike Douglas Show]]''&nbsp;\u2014 Himself (2 episodes, May 15 and May 21, 1970)\n* ''[[The Merv Griffin Show]]''&nbsp;\u2014 Himself (1 episode, May 5, 1970)\n* ''[[The Andy Williams Show]]''&nbsp;\u2014 Himself (1 episode, January 24, 1970)\n* ''[[House Party (radio and TV show)|House Party]]'', a.k.a. ''Art Linkletter's House Party''&nbsp;\u2014 Himself (1 episode, August 24, 1964)\n* ''[[The Ford Show|The Ford Show, Starring Tennessee Ernie Ford]]''&nbsp;\u2014 Himself (Several appearances, 1959\u20131960)\n* ''Sunday Showcase'', aka ''[[NBC Sunday Showcase]]''&nbsp;\u2014 ''The Jimmy Durante Show'' (1959)&nbsp;\u2014 Himself (1 episode, 1959)\n* ''[[The Steve Allen Show]]'', a.k.a. The Steve Allen Plymouth Show (U.S.: new title)&nbsp;\u2014 Himself&nbsp;\u2014 Singer (2 episodes, Nos 4.31/4.4&nbsp;\u2014 1958-1959)\n* ''[[The Ed Sullivan Show|Toast of the Town]]'', a.k.a. ''The Ed Sullivan Show''&nbsp;\u2014 Himself (4 episodes, Nos. 0.50/11.6/11/18/11.36&nbsp;\u2014 1957-1958)\n* The 30th Annual [[Academy Awards]] (1958)&nbsp;\u2014 Himself&nbsp;\u2014 Performer\n* ''[[Shower of Stars]]''&nbsp;\u2014 Himself (1 episode, Comedy Time&nbsp;\u2014 1957)\n* ''The Jimmie Rodgers Show'' TV Series, a.k.a. ''[[Carol Burnett]] Presents the Jimmie Rodgers Show''\n\nIn the mid-1960s, he re-recorded (with altered tunes and words referring to the products) two of his best-known songs, for use in television advertisements:\n* \"Honeycomb\" was adapted for a [[Post Consumer Brands|Post Cereals]] product named \"[[Honeycomb (cereal)|Honeycomb]]\".\n* \"Oh-Oh, I'm Falling in Love Again\" was adapted for one of [[Franco-American (brand)|Franco-American]]'s pasta products: \"Uh-Oh, [[SpaghettiOs]]!\"<ref>{{Cite book |last=Wyman |first=Carolyn |url=https://archive.org/details/betterthanhomema0000wyma_m1j6 |title=Better Than Homemade |publisher=Quirk Books |year=2004 |isbn=9781931686426 |location=Philadelphia, PA |page=[https://archive.org/details/betterthanhomema0000wyma_m1j6/page/124 124] |url-access=registration}}</ref>\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n* {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180614043447/http://www.jimmie-rodgers.com/ |date=14 June 2018 |title=Jimmie Rodgers official website}}\n* {{IMDb name|734720}}\n* {{discogs artist|Jimmie Rodgers (2)}}\n* [https://www.45cat.com/artist/jimmie-rodgers Entry at 45cat.com]\n* [http://www.bsnpubs.com/discog.html Bsnpubs.com]\n* {{Internet Archive short film|id=gov.dod.dimoc.25349|name=\"The Navy Sings It Like It Is (1970)\"}}\n* [http://www.thespectrum.com/story/entertainment/2016/05/26/jimmie-rodgers-singing-and-surviving/84813944/ Interview with Jimmie Rodgers \u2013 The Spectrum, May, 2016.]\n* [https://www.namm.org/library/oral-history/jimmie-rodgers Interview with Jimmie Rodgers - Founded in 2009 by core members Nick Panken (vocals, acoustic guitar), Maggie Carson (five string banjo, vocal), and Stephen Weinheimer (washboard, bass drum, tambourine, vocals), and featuring a rotating cast of musicians such as Ken Woodward (bass, vocals), Or Zubalsky (drums), Noah Block-Harley (fiddle, vocals), Dylan Block-Harley (drums, vocals), [[Twain (musician)|Mat Davidson]] (fiddle, accordion, mandolin, vocals), and Pete Pezzimenti (drums, vocals).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.cleveland.com/minkinsmusic/2015/06/put_your_hands_together_for_sp.html|title=Put Your Hands Together for Spirit Family Reunion|work=cleveland.com}}</ref> They have referred to their style as \"homegrown American music\" and \"open-door gospel\", and are often compared to [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]], [[Country music|country]] and [[Appalachian music|appalachian]] music.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Greene|first1=David|title=Spirit Family Reunion: Music For Church Basements|url=https://www.npr.org/2012/07/29/157532251/spirit-family-reunion-music-for-church-basements|website=NPR Music|publisher=NPR Music|accessdate=August 9, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Minkin|first1=Jay|title=Put Your Hands Together for Spirit Family Reunion|url=http://nodepression.com/live-review/put-your-hands-together-spirit-family-reunion|website=No Depression|accessdate=November 11, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Horowitz|first1=Hal|title=Spirit Family Reunion: Hands Together|url=http://americansongwriter.com/2015/04/spirit-family-reunion-hands-together/|website=American Songwriter|accessdate=November 11, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Jackson|first1=Michael|title=Brooklyn \u2018buskers' Spirit Family Reunion are Bangor-bound|url=http://www.irishnews.com/arts/2016/08/12/news/brooklyn-buskers-spirit-family-reunion-are-bangor-bound-647745/|website=The Irish Times|accessdate=November 11, 2018}}</ref>\n\n== History ==\n\nThe band started out as Panken and Weinheimer playing with different people each night at the bar where they worked, and eventually became Spirit Family Reunion.<ref name=\":0\">{{cite web|url=http://www.abeerwiththeband.com/spirit-family-reunion/?rq=spirit%20family%20reunion|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170428051136/http://www.abeerwiththeband.com/spirit-family-reunion/?rq=spirit%20family%20reunion|url-status=dead|archive-date=April 28, 2017|title=A Beer With Spirit Family Reunion|website=A Beer With the Band|publisher=A Beer With the Band|last1=Mitchell|first1=Kristen|accessdate=August 9, 2015}}</ref> Officially formed in 2010, Spirit Family Reunion has self-produced and self-released two full-length albums, ''No Separation'' (2013) and ''Hands Together'' (2015).<ref>{{cite web|title=About|url=http://www.spiritfamilyreunion.com/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160321121429/http://www.spiritfamilyreunion.com/|url-status=dead|archive-date=March 21, 2016|website=Spirit Family Reunion|accessdate=August 10, 2015}}</ref> They have toured with bands such as [[Trampled by Turtles]], [[Levon Helm]], [[Tedeschi Trucks Band]], [[Dr. Dog]], [[The Felice Brothers]], and [[Alabama Shakes]] and performed at the [[Newport Folk Festival]], [[Hardly Strictly Bluegrass]], [[Celebrate Brooklyn!]], [[FloydFest]], [[Bristol Rhythm & Roots Reunion]], [[Flood City Music Festival]], [[Buckle Up Music Festival|The Buckle Up Music Festival]], [[Shakori Hills Grassroots Festival]], and the [[Americana Music Festival & Conference]] among others.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Leahey|first1=Andrew|title=Hear Spirit Family Reunion Sing Away Blues With 'It Does Not Bother Me'|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/premieres/hear-spirit-family-reunion-sing-away-blues-with-it-does-not-bother-me-20150129|website=Rolling Stone Country|accessdate=August 10, 2015}}</ref> They played a [[Tiny Desk Concerts|Tiny Desk Concert]] in 2012 and took part in the [[Bob Dylan in the 80s: Volume One|''Bob Dylan in the 80s'' project]]. They were also featured in [[The Deli Magazine|issue No. 34 of ''The Deli Magazine'']] in 2013.\n\n== Discography ==\n\n=== Albums ===\n\n* ''No Separation'' (2012)\n* ''Hands Together'' (2015)\n* ''Harvest Festival Live'' (2016)\n* ''Ride Free'' (2019)\n\n=== Extended plays ===\n\n* ''Spirit Family Reunion'' (2010)\n\n=== Singles ===\n\n==== ''When My Name Is Spoken 7\"'' ====\n\n* ''When My Name Is Spoken'' (2010)\n* ''On That Day (2010)\n\n==== ''I Want To Be Relieved 7\"'' ====\n\n* ''I Want To Be Relieved'' (2012)\n* ''Green Rocky Road'' (2012)\n*''Goin' Out To Cannon Ball'' (2016)\n\n==References==\n{{reflist}}\n\n== External links ==\n\n* [http://www.spiritfamilyreunion.com/ Official Website]\n\n[[Category:Musical groups from Brooklyn]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. {{URL|thetallestmanonearth.com/}}\n| instruments      = [[Furch D40]], [[Guild GAD F20]], [[Gretsch Duo Jet]]\n}}\n\n'''Kristian Matsson''' (born 30 April 1983) is a Swedish singer-songwriter who performs under the stage name '''The Tallest Man on Earth'''. Matsson grew up in [[Leksand]], and began his solo career in 2006, having previously been the lead singer of the [[Independent music|indie]] band Montezumas. His music has often drawn comparisons to the music of [[Bob Dylan]].<ref name=\"shallow\">{{cite web |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/shallow-grave-r1437851 |title=Review: Shallow Grave |access-date=14 November 2010 |last=Ross Hoffmann |first=K |publisher=Allmusic.com}}</ref><ref name=\"deadbio\">{{cite web|url=http://www.deadoceans.com/artist.php?name=tallestmanonearth|title=The Tallest Man on Earth|access-date=14 November 2010|publisher=[[Dead Oceans]]|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100202114634/http://www.deadoceans.com/artist.php?name=tallestmanonearth|archive-date=2 February 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=130217980 |title=The Tallest Man on Earth in Concert |access-date=14 November 2010 |last=Hilton |first=Robin |website=NPR.org |publisher=NPR Music}}</ref>\n\nSince 2006, Matsson has released seven full-length albums and four EPs. He records and produces these in his home, and usually records his voice and guitar together on one track. He is known for his charismatic stage presence.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://musicreflections.wordpress.com/2010/09/20/live-review-the-tallest-man-on-earth-antones-sept-18/ |title=Live Review: The Tallest Man On Earth: Antone's; Sept. 18|publisher=Flipsidesounds.com |date=2010-09-20 |access-date=2012-06-29}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Steinborn |first=Derek |url=http://themidwestman.com/2011/02/artist-spotlight-the-tallest-man-on-earth/ |title=Artist Spotlight: The Tallest Man On Earth |publisher=The Midwest Man |date=2011-02-03 |access-date=2012-06-29 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120712071724/http://themidwestman.com/2011/02/artist-spotlight-the-tallest-man-on-earth/ |archive-date=2012-07-12 }}</ref>\n\nHe was previously married to [[Amanda Bergman]], also known by the stage name ''Idiot Wind''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Idiot Wind \u00e4r fortfarande kluven|url=http://www.dt.se/nojekultur/1.5229791-idiot-wind-ar-fortfarande-kluven|publisher=DT|access-date=29 August 2013}}</ref> Together, they wrote the music for the Swedish drama film ''Once a Year''.<ref>Swedish: ''En g\u00e5ng om \u00e5ret''.</ref>\n\n==Musical career==\nBefore Kristian Matsson began his solo career, he was the lead singer of the indie band Montezumas.\n\nMatsson's first solo release, ''[[The Tallest Man on Earth (EP)|The Tallest Man on Earth]]'', was released in 2006. The EP received positive reviews.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/the-tallest-man-on-earth-mw0001489534 |title=The Tallest Man on Earth |access-date=1 March 2016 |last=Deming |first=Mark |publisher=Allmusic.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://kritiker.se/skivor/tallest-man-on-earth/the-tallest-man-on-earth/ |title=The Tallest Man on Earth |department=Review |access-date=1 March 2016 |date=10 April 2010 |publisher=Kritiker.se |df=dmy-all}}</ref>\n\nAt the start of his solo career, Matsson didn't plan to make music full-time, and he released his music without providing personal information or photographs of himself to journalists.<ref name=\"dt\">{{cite news |author=Gustafsson, Anders K. |title=Friheten och musiken viktigast |url=http://www.dt.se/noje/article623930.ece |newspaper=[[Dalarnas Tidningar]] |date=10 April 2010 |access-date=31 December 2010 |language=sv |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100413170355/http://www.dt.se/noje/article623930.ece |archive-date=13 April 2010 |url-status=dead |df=dmy-all}}</ref>\n\nTo celebrate the 10-year anniversary of The Wild Hunt, Matsson released a cover of \"Graceland\" by [[Paul Simon]] through [[Dead Oceans]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.jambase.com/article/tallest-man-on-earth-paul-Simon-cover-graceland/|title= The Tallest Man On Earth Covers Paul Simon's 'Graceland'|access-date=14 April 2020|last=Bernstein|first=Scott|date=14 April 2020}}</ref>\n\n===''Shallow Grave'' (2008\u20132009)===\nIn 2008, Matsson released an album, ''[[Shallow Grave (album)|Shallow Grave]]'', which was praised by the music site [[Pitchfork Media|Pitchfork]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/11359-shallow-graves/ |title=Review: Shallow Grave |access-date=17 November 2010 |last=Petrusich |first=Amanda |date=6 May 2008 |publisher=Pitchfork.com}}</ref> and was listed #47 on Pitchfork's list of the ''50 Best Albums of 2008''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://pitchfork.com/features/staff-lists/7573-the-50-best-albums-of-2008/ |title=The 50 Best Albums of 2008 |access-date=17 November 2010 |publisher=Pitchfork.com}}</ref> The album received generally favorable reviews.<ref name=\"shallow\" /><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sonicmagazine.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=2050&Itemid=85 |title=Recension: Shallow Grave |access-date=17 November 2010 |last=Hellquist |first=Pierre |date=4 March 2008 |publisher=Sonic Magazine}}</ref> Following ''Shallow Grave''<nowiki/>'s release, Matsson was chosen as the opening act for the American indie folk band [[Bon Iver]].<ref name=\"sodra\">{{cite web|url=http://www.sodrateatern.com/sv/Program-och-biljetter/Evenemang/The-Tallest-Man-On-Earth/|title=The Tallest Man on Earth|access-date=17 November 2010|publisher=Sodrateatern.com|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100829011446/http://www.sodrateatern.com/sv/Program-och-biljetter/Evenemang/The-Tallest-Man-On-Earth/|archive-date=29 August 2010}}</ref> The resulting publicity led to a solo tour throughout the United States, Australia and Europe, where he attracted large crowds, in spite of the lack of a record deal or distribution in the United States.<ref name=\"dt\"/>\n\nThe song \"Pistol Dreams\", also released as a single, appeared in the Swedish television serial [[How Soon Is Now? (TV series)|How Soon Is Now?]] <small>(Swedish: Upp till kamp)</small>.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.klicktrack.com/klicktrack/releases/filmmusik-mattias-barjed/upp-till-kamp |title=Soundtrack: Upp till kamp |access-date=17 November 2010 |publisher=Klicktrack.com}}</ref>\n\nOn 9 October 2009, Matsson visited the [[Daytrotter]] studio, where he recorded four songs, including a cover of Bob Dylan's \"I Want You.\"<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.daytrotter.com/dt/the-tallest-man-on-earth-concert/20030843-3738157.html |title=The Tallest Man on Earth |access-date=17 November 2010 |last=Moeller |first=Sean |date=9 October 2009 |publisher=Daytrotter.com |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110524165758/http://www.daytrotter.com/dt/the-tallest-man-on-earth-concert/20030843-3738157.html |archive-date=24 May 2011 }}</ref> At that time, Matsson cited [[Roscoe Holcomb]] as an influence for his singing style<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.transition.se/article.aspx?id=3400 |title=5x5 The Tallest Man on Earth |access-date=17 November 2010 |last=Gunnarsson |first=Fredrik |date=22 September 2008 |publisher=Transition.se |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100818180953/http://www.transition.se/article.aspx?id=3400 |archive-date=18 August 2010 }}</ref> and later included [[Emmylou Harris]], [[Feist (singer)|Feist]] and [[Cat Power]] as influences.<ref>{{cite news |author=Hansson, Nils |title=The Tallest Man on Earth, Idiot Wind p\u00e5 S\u00f6dra teatern |url=http://www.dn.se/kultur-noje/konsertrecensioner/the-tallest-man-on-earth-idiot-wind-pa-sodra-teatern |newspaper=Dagens Nyheter |date=8 December 2010 |language=sv }} (login required)</ref>\n\n===''The Wild Hunt'' (2010\u20132012)===\n[[File:The Tallest Man on Earth 03 - 20101117.jpg|thumb|left|Matsson performing as The Tallest Man on Earth on 17 November 2010]]\n\nMattson signed with the American label [[Dead Oceans]]; in April 2010, he released his second album, ''[[The Wild Hunt (The Tallest Man on Earth album)|The Wild Hunt]]''.<ref name=\"dt\"/> The album was well received.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://kritiker.se/skivor/recension/?skiva=Tallest_Man_On_Earth__-__The_Wild_Hunt |title=Recensioner av The Wild Hunt |access-date=24 November 2010 |publisher=Kritiker.se}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |author=Larson, Annika |title=New Music Tuesday: The Tallest Man on Earth and Two Door Cinema Club |url=http://oudaily.com/news/2010/apr/20/new-music-tuesday-tallest-man-earth-and-two-door-c/ |newspaper=The Oklahoma Daily |date=20 April 2010 |access-date=24 November 2010 |language=en |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100424054439/http://www.oudaily.com/news/2010/apr/20/new-music-tuesday-tallest-man-earth-and-two-door-c/|url-status=dead |archive-date=2010-04-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/14110-the-wild-hunt/ |title=Review: The Wild Hunt |access-date=24 November 2010 |last=Deusner |first=Stephen M. |date=15 April 2010 |publisher=Pitchfork.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/the-wild-hunt-r1736786 |title=Review: The Wild Hunt |access-date=24 November 2010 |last=Ross Hoffman |first=K |publisher=Allmusic.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |author=Howe, Brian |title=Review: The Wild Hunt |url=http://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2010/04/the-tallest-man-on-earth-the-wild-hunt.html |newspaper=Paste Magazine |date=14 April 2010 |language=en }}</ref> The single \"King of Spain\"  contains, besides the title track, a cover of [[Paul Simon]]'s \"Graceland\" and the previously unreleased track \"Where  I Thought I Met the Angels\"; it was sold exclusively at the subsequent European tour. During the late summer and autumn of 2010 Matsson went on tour in North America and Europe.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.deadoceans.com/artist.php?name=tallestmanonearth&p=2|title=The Tallest Man on Earth|access-date=24 November 2010|publisher=Dead Oceans|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111015172343/http://deadoceans.com/artist.php?name=tallestmanonearth&p=2|archive-date=15 October 2011}}</ref>\n\nThe album was followed that same year by an EP, ''[[Sometimes the Blues Is Just a Passing Bird]]'', which also got good reviews.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/sometimes-the-blues-is-just-a-passing-bird-r2027939 |title=Review: Sometimes the Blues is Just a Passing Bird |access-date=24 November 2010 |last=Lymangrover |first=Jason |publisher=Allmusic.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/14639-sometimes-the-blues-is-just-a-passing-bird-ep/ |title=Review: Sometimes the Blues is Just a Passing Bird |access-date=24 November 2010 |last=Deusner |first=Stephen M. |date=16 September 2010 |publisher=Pitchfork.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=The Tallest Man on Earth |url=http://www.dt.se/noje/skivor/article745418.ece |newspaper=Dalarnas Tidningar |access-date=24 November 2010 |language=sv |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101012084709/http://www.dt.se/noje/skivor/article745418.ece|url-status=dead|archive-date=2010-10-12}}</ref> The EP was released through the iTunes Store in September, and in November was published on CD, LP and MP3. The album consists of five songs, all written for ''The Wild Hunt''; \"Like the Wheel\" the conclusion of many of Matsson's gigs, and \"The Dreamer\", was the first recording on which he plays electric guitar.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://deadoceans.com/blog/2010/09/surprise-new-ep-from-the-tallest-man-on-earth-available-for-download-today-on-itunes/ |title=Surprise! New EP from The Tallest Man on Earth Available for Download Today on iTunes |access-date=24 November 2010 |date=7 September 2010 |publisher=Dead Oceans |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100913134943/http://deadoceans.com/blog/2010/09/surprise-new-ep-from-the-tallest-man-on-earth-available-for-download-today-on-itunes/ |archive-date=13 September 2010 |url-status=dead |df=dmy-all }}</ref>\n\n''The Wild Hunt'' garnered Matsson several award nominations. In 2011, he was nominated in the category \"Best Male Artist\" in [[Grammis|the Grammis Awards]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://poplight.zitiz.se/artikel/poplight-tippar-grammisvinnarna |title=Poplight tippar vinnarna p\u00e5 Grammisgalan 2011 |access-date=23 January 2011 |last=Linde |first=Eva |date=16 January 2011 |publisher=Poplight}}</ref> the Swedish equivalent of the American [[Grammy Award]]s, but lost to [[H\u00e5kan Hellstr\u00f6m]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://poplight.zitiz.se/artikel/robyn-och-hakan-hellstroem-dominerade-grammisgalan-2011 |title=Robyn och H\u00e5kan Hellstr\u00f6m dominerade Grammisgalan 2011 |access-date=23 January 2011 |last=Dahlander |first=Gustav |date=17 January 2011 |publisher=Poplight |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120316052909/http://poplight.zitiz.se/artikel/robyn-och-hakan-hellstroem-dominerade-grammisgalan-2011 |archive-date=16 March 2012 |url-status=dead |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Matsson was also nominated in the category \"pop\" in the 2011 [[P3 Guld|P3 Gold Awards]],<ref>{{cite news |url=http://sverigesradio.se/sida/artikel.aspx?programid=3964&artikel=4220806 |title=Alla nominerade till P3 Guld 2011 |access-date=16 February 2011 |newspaper=Sveriges radio|date=7 December 2010 }}</ref> but lost to Malm\u00f6 indie pop band This Is Head.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://sverigesradio.se/sida/gruppsida.aspx?programid=3964&grupp=13659 |title=Vinnarna i P3 Guld 2011 |access-date=16 February 2011 |publisher=Sveriges radio}}</ref> In February 2011, Matsson won the Manifest Award in the \"singer/songwriter\" category; he was also nominated in the \"live\" category, lost to [[Robyn]].<ref>{{cite news |author=Gustafsson, Anders K |title=Tallest Man on Earth fick Manifestpris |url=http://www.dt.se/noje/musik/article887188.ece |newspaper=Dalarnas Tidningar |date=5 February 2011 |access-date=3 March 2011 |language=sv |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110209112323/http://www.dt.se/noje/musik/article887188.ece|url-status=dead |archive-date=2011-02-09}}</ref>\n\nOn 5 April 2011, Matsson participated in the BBC's program, ''[[Later... with Jools Holland]]'', where he performed the songs \"King of Spain\" and \"Love Is All\".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://deadoceans.com/blog/2011/04/tallest-man-on-earth-on-bbcs-later-with-jools-holland/#more-2400 |title=Tallest Man on Earth on BBC's Later with Jools Holland |access-date=12 April 2011 |date=8 April 2011 |publisher=Dead Oceans |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111015172336/http://deadoceans.com/blog/2011/04/tallest-man-on-earth-on-bbcs-later-with-jools-holland/#more-2400 |archive-date=15 October 2011 |url-status=dead |df=dmy-all }}</ref> In June of the same year, Matsson's debut EP, The Tallest Man on Earth, was reissued with the previously unreleased track \"In the Pockets\" exclusive to the vinyl edition of the reissue. In July, he released the single \"Weather of a Killing Kind\" as part of the 2011 Adult Swim Singles program.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.impossibletrees.com/2011/07/weather-of-a-killing-kind-available-for-free-download/|title=Weather of a Killing Kind|access-date=12 July 2011|publisher=Impossibletrees.com|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111204020402/http://www.impossibletrees.com/2011/07/weather-of-a-killing-kind-available-for-free-download/|archive-date=4 December 2011}}</ref>\n\nIn August 2011, Matsson had contributed to the soundtrack of the Swedish drama film ''En g\u00e5ng om \u00e5ret'' <small>(English: Once a Year)</small>, along with the [[Amanda Bergman|Idiot Wind]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2011/08/the-tallest-man-on-earth-and-idiot-wind-to-score-f.html|title=The Tallest Man On Earth and Idiot Wind to Score Film |access-date=12 July 2011 |publisher=Paste Magazine}}</ref> The film premiered at the [[Gothenburg Film Festival]] on 29 January 2012 and had a theatrical release on 17 May 2013.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sfi.se/sv/svensk-filmdatabas/Item/?itemid=75431&type=MOVIE&iv=Basic&ref=/templates/SwedishFilmSearchResult.aspx?id%3d1225%26epslanguage%3dsv%26searchword%3dEn+g%C3%A5ng+om+%C3%A5ret%26type%3dMovieTitle%26match%3dBegin%26page%3d1%26prom%3dFalse |title=''En g\u00e5ng om \u00e5ret'' |access-date=23 July 2013 |publisher=Svensk Filmdatabas}}</ref>\n\nOn 27 January 2012, Matsson took part in the Swedish [[TV]] [[game show]], P\u00e5 sp\u00e5ret where he, backed by a studio band, performed two cover songs: Thin Lizzy's \"Dancing in the Moonlight\" and  Cornelis Vreeswijk's \"En  Fattig Trubadur\" <small>(English: A Poor Troubadour)</small>.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadoceans.com/blog/2012/02/the-tallest-man-on-earth-plays-thin-lizzy-cover-on-swedish-game-show/|title=The Tallest Man on Earth Plays Thin Lizzy Cover on Swedish Game Show|access-date=11 June 2012|publisher=Dead Oceans|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120505192732/http://deadoceans.com/blog/2012/02/the-tallest-man-on-earth-plays-thin-lizzy-cover-on-swedish-game-show/|archive-date=5 May 2012|url-status=dead|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In February of that year, he re-released \"King of Spain\" as 12\" vinyl for the event Record Store Day. the album was limited to 2000 copies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadoceans.com/blog/2012/02/the-tallest-man-on-earth-releases-12-for-record-store-day-2012/|title=The Tallest Man On Earth Releases Exclusive 12\u2033 for Record Store Day 2012|access-date=11 June 2012|publisher=Dead Oceans|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120511074758/http://deadoceans.com/blog/2012/02/the-tallest-man-on-earth-releases-12-for-record-store-day-2012/|archive-date=11 May 2012|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n\n===''There's No Leaving Now'' (2012\u20132013)===\n[[File:KristianMatsson 20130615.jpg|thumb|Mattsson performing as The Tallest Man on Earth at Bonnaroo 2013]]\n\nOn 12 June 2012 (June 11 in the UK), Matsson released his third studio album as The Tallest Man on Earth, ''[[There's No Leaving Now]]'', on [[Dead Oceans]]. The album was recorded by Matsson himself in his home studio in Dalarna during the latter part of 2011 and early 2012.<ref name=\"deadbio\"/> The album was streamed on Dead Oceans' website a week before its official release.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadoceans.com/blog/2012/06/the-tallest-man-on-earths-theres-no-leaving-now-available-for-streaming/|title=LISTEN: The Tallest Man On Earth's \"There's No Leaving Now\" Available for Streaming on NPR|access-date=11 June 2012|publisher=Dead Oceans|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120609010236/http://deadoceans.com/blog/2012/06/the-tallest-man-on-earths-theres-no-leaving-now-available-for-streaming/|archive-date=9 June 2012|url-status=dead|df=dmy-all}}</ref>\n\nAt the same time, Matsson released ''1904 b/w Cycles'', a 7\" LP of his song \"1904\" as well his cover of the song \"Cycles,\" written by Gayle Caldwell and [[Cycles (Frank Sinatra album)|made famous by Frank Sinatra]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=The Tallest Man On Earth \u2013 1904 (2012, Vinyl)|url=https://www.discogs.com/The-Tallest-Man-On-Earth-1904/release/3660631|access-date=2020-12-16|website=Discogs|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=the tallest man on earth \u2013 Page 3 \u2013 Indie Music Filter|url=https://indiemusicfilter.com/tag/the-tallest-man-on-earth/page/3|access-date=2020-12-16|website=indiemusicfilter.com}}</ref> He has also covered this song in live performances.<ref>{{Cite web|title=The Tallest Man on Earth and Idiot Wind Cover \"Cycles\" \u2013 TwentyFourBit|date=5 May 2012 |url=https://www.twentyfourbit.com/2012/05/the-tallest-man-on-earth-and-idiot-wind-cover-cycles/|access-date=2020-12-16|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=Rydin|first=Brent|date=2012-05-09|title=Idiot Wind and The Tallest Man on Earth Breeze Through Sinatra's \"Cycles\"|url=https://www.covermesongs.com/2012/05/idiot-wind-and-the-tallest-man-on-earth-breeze-through-sinatras-cycles.html|access-date=2020-12-16|website=Cover Me|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Top 10 Sinatra covers|url=https://radiomilwaukee.org/discover-music/music-news/top-10-covers-of-sinatra-on-his-100th-birthday/|access-date=2020-12-16|website=88Nine Radio Milwaukee|date=12 December 2015 |language=en-US}}</ref>\n\nAlong with the album, Matsson announced a summer tour throughout Europe and the United States including two gigs in Sweden (at the [[S\u00f6dra Teatern]] <small>(English: Southern Theatre)</small> in [[Stockholm]]) and a performance at the [[Newport Folk Festival]] in [[Newport, Rhode Island]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadoceans.com/blog/2012/03/the-tallest-man-on-earth-announces-new-album-theres-no-leaving-now-and-select-summer-tour-dates/|title=The Tallest Man On Earth Announces New Album \"There's No Leaving Now,\" & Select Summer Tour Dates|access-date=11 June 2012|publisher=Dead Oceans|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120511073738/http://deadoceans.com/blog/2012/03/the-tallest-man-on-earth-announces-new-album-theres-no-leaving-now-and-select-summer-tour-dates/|archive-date=11 May 2012|url-status=dead|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Matsson also toured in Europe in October 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadoceans.com/blog/2012/05/the-tallest-man-on-earth-announce-new-tour-dates/|title=The Tallest Man On Earth Announces New Tour Dates|access-date=11 June 2012|publisher=Dead Oceans|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120613221054/http://deadoceans.com/blog/2012/05/the-tallest-man-on-earth-announce-new-tour-dates/|archive-date=13 June 2012|url-status=dead|df=dmy-all}}</ref>\n\nOn 28 January 2013, Matsson took part in a benefit concert for the American musician [[Jason Molina]], who did not have health insurance and, consequently, was in debt after a hospital stay. The concert took place at the S\u00f6dra Teatern <small>(English: Southern Theatre)</small> in [[Stockholm]], where Matsson played alongside, among others, I'm Kingfisher and [[Amanda Bergman|Idiot Wind]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sodrateatern.com/sv/Program-och-biljetter/Evenemang/Cross-the-Road-Molina/|title=Cross the Road Molina|access-date=29 January 2013|publisher=S\u00f6dra Teatern}}{{Dead link|date=June 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }}</ref> Molina died on 16 March 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://pitchfork.com/news/50000-rip-jason-molina/|title=R.I.P. Jason Molina|website=Pitchfork|date=18 March 2013 |access-date=28 June 2019}}</ref>\n\n===''Dark Bird Is Home'' (2015)===\nMatsson's fourth studio album as The Tallest Man on Earth, ''[[Dark Bird Is Home]]'', was released on 12 May 2015 on [[Dead Oceans]]. The album was largely inspired by Matsson's divorce from [[Amanda Bergman]] as well as the death of a close family member, and its more elaborate instrumentation represented a musical shift from previous albums.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Barton|first1=Laura|title=The Tallest Man on Earth: 'It feels like such a freedom to be loud'|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/jun/23/the-tallest-man-on-earth-dark-bird-is-home-interview|website=The Guardian|date=23 June 2015 |access-date=10 June 2017}}</ref>\n\nFollowing its release, Matsson performed\u2014with a full band\u2014at several festivals, including the [[Roskilde Festival]] in 2015<ref>{{cite web |url=http://pitchfork.com/news/58399-the-tallest-man-on-earth-returns-with-new-album-dark-bird-is-home/ |title=''Dark Bird Is Home'' |access-date=14 February 2015 |last=Gordon |first=Jeremy |date=10 February 2015 |publisher=Pitchfork}}</ref> and the [[Edmonton Folk Music Festival]] in 2016.<ref>[http://www.edmontonsun.com/2016/08/07/2016-edmonton-folk-fest-an-understated-wonderful-weekend \" 2016 Edmonton Folk Fest an understated, wonderful weekend\"]. ''Edmonton Sun'', By Fish Griwkowsky. August 07, 2016</ref>\n\n===''I Love You. It's a Fever Dream.'' (2019)===\nOn 4 February 2019, Matsson revealed that a new album would be released in 2019. In late February 2019, he revealed that his new album, now titled ''[[I Love You. It's a Fever Dream.]]'', would be released sometime in April. He also released the first single, \"The Running Styles of New York\" the same day. The second single, \"I'm a Stranger Now\" was released on 27 March. The album was released on April 19 2019.\n\nMatsson's song ''It Will Follow the Rain'' from his [[eponymous]] EP was featured in a 2019 commercial for the [[Infiniti QX50]] automobile.\n\n===''Too Late for Edelweiss'' (2022)===\nOn 19 September 2022, Matsson announced a new album of covers. It was released later that week on 23 September 2022 and includes covers of songs from [[The National (band)|The National]] and [[Bon Iver]], among others. The album's title, ''Too Late for Edelweiss'', is a reference to the album ''[[F\u00f6r sent f\u00f6r Edelweiss]]'' by Swedish singer [[H\u00e5kan Hellstr\u00f6m]], the title track of which is the first song covered on the album.<ref name=\"pitchfork-edelweiss\">{{Cite web |title=The Tallest Man on Earth Announces New Covers Album Too Late for Edelweiss |last=Arcand |first=Rob |work=[[Pitchfork (website)|Pitchfork]] |date=19 September 2022 |access-date=23 September 2022 |url= https://pitchfork.com/news/the-tallest-man-on-earth-announces-new-covers-album-too-late-for-edelweiss/ }}</ref>\n\n===''Henry St.'' (2023)===\nOn 1 February 2023, Matsson revealed that a new album titled ''Henry St.'' would be released on 14 April 2023.<ref>{{Cite web |last=ANTI- |title=The Tallest Man On Earth Announces Henry St., First New Album in Four Years, Out April 14th Via ANTI-, And Spring North American Tour Dates {{!}} News |url=http://www.anti.com/news/the-tallest-man-on-earth-announces-henry-st-first-new-album-in-four-years-o/ |access-date=2023-02-12 |website=Anti Records |language=en}}</ref> ''Henry St.'' is the first of Mattson's albums recorded in a band setting. The announcement of the album was followed by the release of the single \"Every Little Heart\". On 19 April, five days after the album's release, Pitchfork gave the album a 6.0,<ref name=\"Currin\">{{cite web |last1=Currin |first1=Grayson Haver |title=The Tallest Man on Earth: Henry St. |url=https://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/the-tallest-man-on-earth-henry-st/ |website=Pitchfork |access-date=19 April 2023 |ref=2}}</ref> praising the instrumentals and full-band sound but saying that the writing was \"just bad\". Writing for ''[[No Depression (magazine)|No Depression]]'', John Amen concluded that \"While Matsson\u2019s latest set occasionally loses traction, it certainly includes its memorable moments, most of which reiterate the confessional pitch and rougher vocal stylings of his earlier work.\"<ref>{{Cite web |title=ALBUM REVIEW: The Tallest Man on Earth Hones Craft and Wisdom on 'Henry St.' |url=https://www.nodepression.com/album-reviews/album-review-the-tallest-man-on-earth-hones-craft-and-wisdom-on-henry-st/ |access-date=2023-04-29 |website=No Depression |language=en-US}}</ref>\n\n==Musical style==\nCritics have compared The Tallest Man on Earth to [[Bob Dylan]] both in terms of songwriting ability and vocal style.<ref name=nyt10Dec2008>{{cite news|last=Pareles|first=Jon|title=Two Variations on an Acoustic Theme|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/12/11/arts/music/11nadl.html|access-date=7 April 2011|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=10 December 2008}}</ref><ref name=bglobe4Oct2010>{{cite news|last=O'Neil|first=Luke|title=Tallest Man on Earth is a player with range|url=http://www.boston.com/ae/music/articles/2010/10/04/tallest_man_on_earth_is_a_player_with_range/|access-date=7 April 2011|newspaper=[[The Boston Globe]]|date=4 October 2010}}</ref><ref name=ind9Apr2010>{{cite news|last=Gill|first=Andy|title=Album: The Tallest Man On Earth, The Wild Hunt (Dead Oceans)|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/reviews/album-the-tallest-man-on-earth-the-wild-hunt-dead-oceans-1939532.html |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/archive/20220620/https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/reviews/album-the-tallest-man-on-earth-the-wild-hunt-dead-oceans-1939532.html |archive-date=2022-06-20 |url-access=subscription |url-status=live|access-date=7 April 2011|newspaper=[[The Independent]]|date=9 April 2010}}</ref> When asked about his lyrical style, Matsson explains that he began listening to Bob Dylan at fifteen, and upon hearing Dylan's cover material, he \"tried to figure out where those songs came from\" and became slowly exposed to early American folk, such as [[Pete Seeger]] and [[Woody Guthrie]]. But he is careful to qualify this, saying \"I don't consider my work to be a part of any tradition. This is how I play. This is how I write songs.\"<ref name=\"youtube1\">{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oQAV7cRDbWA |title=The Tallest Man On Earth interview - Suhaib Shaikh (part 1) |date=25 March 2010 |publisher=YouTube |access-date=2012-06-29}}</ref>\n\nWith regard to his guitar technique, Matsson uses a variety of [[open tunings]], and standard tuning to a lesser degree. He had classical guitar training in his youth, but says he \"never really focused on it\" and that by the end of high school he \"got bored playing guitar because it was like math\",<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=q2IX5FoRRis&feature=relmfu |title=The Tallest Man On Earth interview - Kristian Matsson (part 3) |date=12 September 2011 |publisher=YouTube |access-date=2012-06-29}}</ref> until he then discovered open tunings while listening to [[Nick Drake]] in his early twenties. He was drawn to this style of playing because it allowed him to focus on singing while still performing intricate music.\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|+ List of albums, with selected chart positions, sales, and certifications\n! scope=\"column\" rowspan=\"2\"|Title\n! scope=\"column\" rowspan=\"2\"|Details\n! scope=\"column\" colspan=\"10\"|Peak chart positions\n|-\n! scope=\"col\" style=\"width:3em;font-size:90%;\"|[[Sverigetopplistan|SWE]]<br/><ref>{{cite web | url = http://swedishcharts.com/search.asp?search=The+Tallest+Man+on+Earth&cat=a | publisher = Swedishcharts.com. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Nothin'_Fancy","to":"Nothin' Fancy"}],"pages":{"15727628":{"pageid":15727628,"ns":0,"title":"Nothin' Fancy","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|Bluegrass band from Virginia, US}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name             = Nothin' Fancy\n| background       = group_or_band\n| image            = Nothin' Fancy with SPBGMA award trophy Nashville TN February 2009.jpg\n| landscape        = yes\n| caption          = \"Entertaining Group Of The Year\"<br />35th Annual National [http://www.spbgma.com/ SPBGMA] Awards<br />February 5, 2009\n| origin           = [[Timberville, Virginia]], [[United States]]<br />[[Buena Vista, Virginia]]<br />[[Lexington, Virginia]]<br />[[Manassas, Virginia]]\n| genre            = {{hlist|[[Folk music|Folk]]|[[Country music|country]]|[[Americana (music)|Americana]]|[[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]]}}\n| years_active     = 1994&ndash;present\n| label            = {{hlist|[[Mountain Fever Records|Mountain Fever]]|[[Pinecastle Records|Pinecastle]]}}\n| website          = [http://www.nothinfancybluegrass.com/ Official Site]\n| current_members  = Mike Andes<br /> Chris Sexton<br />James Cox<br />Jacob Flick<br />Curt Gausman\n| past_members     = Gary Farris<br /> Buster Sexton<br />Frankie Hawkins<br />Darin Lawrence<br />Bill Ledbetter<br />Eli Johnston<br  />Justin Tomlin<br />Jesse Smathers<br />Tony Shorter<br/> Mitchell Davis<br />Caleb Cox<br />Jake Lauzon\n}}\n'''Nothin' Fancy'''<ref name=belleville>[http://www.insidebelleville.com/whatson-story/3956437-nothing-fancy-is-fancy-perfection/ \"Nothing Fancy is fancy perfection\"]. ''Inside Belleville'', May 03, 2012</ref> is a [[bluegrass music|bluegrass]] [[musical group|band]] based in [[Buena Vista, Virginia]] and was formed in September 1994. Its \"parent band\"{{clarify|date=June 2022}} East Coast Bluegrass Band was formed Summer 1985 to compete in the East Coast Bluegrass Championship in [[Crimora, Virginia]].<ref>*[http://bluegrasscountry.org/programs/aotm/nothin-fancy/ Bluegrass Country] profile \"October 2004: Nothin' Fancy\".</ref>\n\n== History ==\n=== East Coast Bluegrass Band ===\nThe East Coast Bluegrass Band was the predecessor to Nothin' Fancy formed in 1985. It was formed to compete in the East Coast Bluegrass Championship in [[Crimora, Virginia]].<ref name=belleville /> In 1986 the group won the Virginia Folk Music Society State Bluegrass Band Championship.<ref name=\"samhillbands.com\">[http://www.samhillbands.com/bands/eastcoast/index.shtml \"Biography: East Coast Bluegrass Band\"] Sam Hill Entertainment.</ref> After winning the contest, the band continued to play together at local functions.   The members of the band developed some original material, but remained true to the traditional style of the great [[bluegrass band]]s of the 1940s and 1950s.<ref name=\"samhillbands.com\"/> Nothin' Fancy was formed in 1994. Mike Andes and Mitchell Davis joined forces with Gary Farris on guitar, Tony Shorter on bass, and Guy Carawan on fiddle to play the same East Coast Bluegrass Championship in September 1994 that East Coast Bluegrass Band had once played almost a decade earlier. Nothin' Fancy released their first project \"Bluegrass in a Plain Brown Wrapper\" shortly afterwards.\n\nNothin' Fancy and East Coast Bluegrass Band continued to coexist until 2000 when East Coast Bluegrass Band's members drifted apart and had to reorganize.\n\n=== Notable Changes ===\nChris Sexton, who had appeared with Nothin' Fancy for their first-place victory in the band competition at the Maury River Fiddler's Convention in 1998 and recorded as a guest fiddler on the band's second and third releases (\"Earn Your Ticket\" and \"Field of Dreams,\" respectively), officially became the newest member of Nothin' Fancy in 2000.  The fourth project, ''Now and Then'' is the first album to feature the five-piece group as it is today.\n\nShorter departed from the group in 2005, and was replaced by Eli Johnston of [[Branson, MO]].  Nothin' Fancy released \"Album No.&nbsp;7\" under Pinecastle with Johnston and featured him as the lead vocal on the song \"Tupelo County Jail,\" but Johnston only stayed with the group for 13 months.  Citing artistic differences, he left the group and joined the band Pine Mountain Railroad.  Nothin' Fancy's members called Shorter back into service in time for the 6th Annual Nothin' Fancy Bluegrass Festival.  Shorter, who at the time was playing bass for country star [[Keith Bryant]], happily agreed and the band was re-united with its original cast and has stayed as such since.\n\nGary Farris, the guitar player, also departed the group in July 2012 and was replaced by Justin Tomlin.<ref>[http://bluegrasstoday.com/justin-tomlin-to-nothin-fancy/ \"Justin Tomlin to Nothin\u2019 Fancy\"]. ''Bluegrass Today''.</ref> Tomlin left in March 2014, and Jesse Smathers joined the group in his place.<ref>[http://bluegrasstoday.com/jesse-smathers-to-nothin-fancy \"Jesse Smathers to Nothin Fancy\"]. ''Bluegrass Today''.</ref> In June 2015, Jesse Smathers departed the group and was replaced by guitar and dobro player, Caleb Cox.<ref>[http://bluegrasstoday.com/jesse-smathers-to-lonesome-river-band \"Jesse Smathers to Lonesome River Band\"]. ''Bluegrass Today''.</ref> A month later, the band signed a recording contract with Mountain Fever Records and released their first project for the label \"By Any Other Name\" in August 2015.<ref>[http://bluegrasstoday.com/nothin-fancy-to-mountain-fever \"Nothin\u2019 Fancy to Mountain Fever\"]. ''Bluegrass Today''.</ref>\n\nIn 2019, founding member Mitchell Davis announced that he would be leaving the band. Following his departure, the band announced in March of that year that it had signed on Jacob Flick to take up Davis' role on the banjo.<ref>[https://bluegrasstoday.com/jacob-flick-to-nothin-fancy \"Jacob Flick to Nothin\u2019 Fancy\"]. ''Bluegrass Today''.</ref>\n\nIn June 2021, it was announced that Jacobe \"Jake\" Lauzon would be joining the band to play guitar and provide vocals. Jake, originally from Ontario, Canada, was a welcome addition to the group, having been was recognized as the Bluegrass Guitar Player of the Year in 2018 and 2019 at the Central Canadian Bluegrass Awards.<ref>[https://bluegrasstoday.com/jake-lauzon-to-nothin-fancy-on-guitar/ \"Jake Lauzon to Nothin\u2019 Fancy\"]. ''Bluegrass Today''.</ref>\n\nIn September 2022, it was announced that Jake Lauzon would be departing from the band to pursue new musical interests after playing one final set at the 20th Nothin' Fancy Festival.\n\nIn December 2022, the band announced that it had found its new guitar player, Curt Gausman. Curt, who got his bluegrass start in the 1980s, was part of Hobbs and Partners, which was led by Arnold Hobbs. The group also included John Paganoni, John\u2019s son Chris (who filled in as a substitute with Nothin\u2019 Fancy on more than one occasion), and Mark Delaney. From his work with Hobbs, he later formed the Hazel River Band, which he led through 1996 and recorded two albums with the Hay Holler label. <ref>[https://bluegrasstoday.com/curt-gausman-to-nothin-fancy/ \"Curt Gausman to Nothin\u2019 Fancy\"]. ''Bluegrass Today''.</ref>\n\n== Recordings ==\n\nEast Coast Bluegrass Band released four self-produced albums.  They then contracted [[Tim Austin]] of [[Doobie Shea Records|Doobie Shea Studios]] to produce and record the project. Recording began in February 1996. Later that spring, lightning struck and destroyed the studio and all the recorded sessions. Once it was up and running again they were one of the first acts to record in the new studio.<ref name=\"samhillbands.com\"/> After four albums, thirteen years, and hundreds of performances, the band released their first nationally distributed recording project, ''Life's Mysteries'' on [[Copper Creek Records]].\n\nThe group, now appearing as Nothin' Fancy, was approached by [[Pinecastle Records]] and signed to the label in 2002.  They recorded their fifth project, \"Once Upon a Road\" with the title song written for the band by [[Tom T. Hall]] and his wife Dixie.  \"Once Upon a Road\" rose to number 10 on the Bluegrass Charts as posted by [[Bluegrass Unlimited]].  Their bluegrass gospel song \"When the Angels Take My Hand\" rose to the Number 1 spot on the Bluegrass Gospel charts as posted by (the now-defunct) ''Bluegrass Now'' magazine.  The album also earned them a showcase at the [[International Bluegrass Music Association]] (IBMA) Convention in October 2002 and a nomination for the [[International Bluegrass Music Awards|IBMA]] Emerging Artist of the Year Award.\n\nTheir sixth album, \"Reflections,\" was a much more personal album, with Andes penning 10 of the 13 songs.  It featured the novelty single \"I Met My Baby in the Porta-John Line\" as a bonus track, also by Andes.  \"Reflections\" was not as commercially successful as \"Once Upon a Road,\" but it was from these two albums and the performances from this period that Nothin' Fancy had found its highly unique voice, which paid homage to bands such as the [[The Country Gentlemen|Country Gentlemen]] and the [[Seldom Scene]].  The late [[Charlie Waller (American musician)|Charlie Waller]], a founding member of the [[The Country Gentlemen|Country Gentlemen]] who went on to lead that group until his death in 2004, met with Andes at the [http://www.spbgma.com/ Society for the Preservation of Bluegrass Music of America] annual convention and learned the song \"Heaven Got an Angel\" from Andes (that was recorded originally on \"Field of Dreams\") and recorded it on the [[The Country Gentlemen|Country Gentlemen]] album \"Cryin' in the Chapel.\"\n\nTheir eighth album, ''Lord Bless This House'', the first all-gospel recording for the group, was officially released January 27, 2009 through [http://www.pinecastle.com/ Pinecastle].  Co-produced by Grammy-nominated bluegrass artist [[Rhonda Vincent]] and her brother Darrin Vincent (of Dailey and Vincent fame) with guest appearances from the both of them, it is frequently played on [[Sirius XM]] Radio's [[Bluegrass Junction]] station, along with other selections from their discography.\n\n''Undeniable'' is the group's 16th studio recording, released in 2019 to celebrate their 25th year together. The album includes all-original songwriting by Mike Andes, Caleb Cox, and Chris Sexton. It features Mike Andes (mandolin, lead/harmony vocals), Chris Sexton (fiddle, harmony vocals), Caleb Cox (guitar, lead/harmony vocals), James Cox (bass), and Jacob Flick (banjo). Cello, viola, and string arrangements on \u201cHere\u2019s To My Life\u201d were provided by Chris Sexton. The album was recorded, mixed, and mastered at Mountain Fever Studios in [[Willis, Floyd County, Virginia|Willis, Virginia]] and released by [[Mountain Fever Records]].\n\n== Performance ==\n\nEast Coast Bluegrass Band paid their dues at lawn parties and bars in and around the [[Harrisonburg, Virginia]] area and the [[Charlottesville, Virginia]] area for many years.  In years since, the band, as Nothin' Fancy, has played the [[Grand Ole Opry]] at the historic [[Ryman Auditorium]] in [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]],<ref>[http://www.bluegrassworks.com/profile.php?profileID=31 Bluegrass Works] interview \"Nothin' Fancy\" with Loretta Sawyer, 03/25/2004.</ref> and with the \"Bluegrass Series with [[Rhonda Vincent]] & Nothin' Fancy\".<ref>[http://nemr.net/~rhondav/ Official Website] Rhonda Vincent.</ref> They have played such other major venues as [[Lincoln Center]] in [[New York City]], and [[The Birchmere]] in [[Alexandria, Virginia]].  Nothin' Fancy plays about 140 shows a year and is a staple on the bluegrass festival circuit.<ref>[http://journalstar.com/articles/2007/09/28/living/gz/performances/doc46fb0ee5f118e173797113.txt Lincoln Journal Star] \"Members of Nothin' Fancy tell bluegrass listeners to expect something different\" by L. Kent Wolgamott, September 28, 2007.</ref> The band has been known to take fans on bus trips to festivals and accompanying them on bluegrass cruises aboard the [[Royal Caribbean International|Royal Caribbean]] and [[Carnival]] cruises.<ref>[http://bluegrasscountry.org/programs/aotm/nothin-fancy/ Bluegrass Country] profile \"October 2004: Nothin' Fancy\".</ref> Nothin' Fancy performed in June 2010 at the Tottenhan Bluegrass Festival in [[Ontario, Canada]], and the band toured as part of the 2012 Bluegrass Sundays Winter Concert series organized by the Northern Bluegrass Committee in Scarborough, Ontario.<ref>\"Bluegrass Sundays\" concert program, Northern Bluegrass Committee, 2012</ref>\n\n== Musical style and sound ==\nThe band seeks to remain \"true to the traditional sounds of the great bluegrass bands of the 1940s and '50s\",<ref name=\"samhillbands.com\"/> while also performing and recording original songs by their prolific songwriter, lead singer Mike Andes.  Classic bluegrass material draws from [[Bill Monroe]], [[Ralph Stanley]], the [[The Country Gentlemen|Country Gentlemen]], and the [[Seldom Scene]]; but song selection ranges from original material to gospel classics to covers of pop artists such as [[Bob Seger]], [[Bruce Springsteen]], [[Bill Withers]], [[Bob Dylan]], and [[Creedence Clearwater Revival]].\n\nIn live performance Nothin' Fancy has been noted for its strong vocals, four-part arrangements, and its high-energy shows well-seasoned with humor.  The quintet's early years saw the band gathering around one microphone, employing a shell-game choreography for solos and back-up which keeps the show visually active as well as aurally pleasing, although the most recent configuration is more traditional with individual microphones for instruments and vocals. Andes' clear singing style is attributed to the unique stylings of [[Charlie Waller (American musician)|Charlie Waller]], whose earthy bass-baritone voice sang with clear enunciation.  Farris sings a bold tenor harmony remarkable for its projection; his powerful delivery has been likened to the late [[John Duffey]] of the [[Seldom Scene]].  Shorter occasionally sings baritone harmonies an octave higher, while Davis sings bass vocals, more on gospel songs. In later recordings, Davis gave up singing bass and allowed Sexton to sing bass on gospel songs\n\n==Nothin' Fancy Bluegrass Festival==\nIn 2001, a Rockbridge County entrepreneur, Morris O'Shields, created a bluegrass festival at the Glen Maury Park, the site of the Maury River Fiddler's Convention where Nothin' Fancy won its victory three years before.  The festival was named for Nothin' Fancy, who have served as the host act in years since.<ref>[http://www.rockbridgeweekly.com/rw_article.php?ndx=9737 Rockbridge Weekly] \"Virginia Based Bluegrass Band Nothin' Fancy Garners National Music Award\".</ref>  Just as the band originally named itself after the first music festival in which it competed\u2014subsequently winning the prize\u2014it then had a music festival, whose competition it had also won, subsequently named for it.\n\nThe so-named festival has become a much-loved annual event that brings scores of bluegrass fans to the [[Shenandoah Valley]] and to the little town of [[Buena Vista, VA]], where Farris calls home (and from which the band operates).  Held each year at the Glen Maury Park in [[Buena Vista, Virginia]], the [[music festival|festival]] has perennially played host to major [[bluegrass music|bluegrass]] [[musical group|band]]s.  The 2008 [[music festival|festival]], for example, included such names as [[Rhonda Vincent]], [[Michelle Nixon]], Blue Mountain Sunrise, The Deer Creek Boys, [[The Country Gentlemen|Randy Waller & the Country Gentlemen]], Blue Moon Rising, and the [http://www.thegarywaldrepband.com/ Gary Waldrep Band].<ref>*[http://www.cybergrass.com/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=5313 Cybergrass] \"SPBGMA Entertaining Group Of The Year Nothin' Fancy To Host Bluegrass Fest\" September 10, 2008.</ref>  It has also hosted bands and artists such as [[IIIrd Tyme Out]], the [http://www.lonesomeriverband.com/ Lonesome River Band], [[Missy Raines]], [[Marty Raybon]], [[The Dillards]], the [[Lewis Family]], [http://www.goldwingexpress.net/ Goldwing Express], [http://www.larrystephensonband.com/ Larry Stephenson], [http://www.marknewtonband.com/ Mark Newton], [[Doyle Lawson]], and [http://www.charliesizemoreband.com/ Charlie Sizemore].\n\n==Discography==\n*''Bluegrass In A Plain Brown Wrapper'' singer-songwriter (1932\u20132024)}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2020}}\n{{Sources|date=September 2024}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Billy Edd Wheeler\n| image           =\n| caption         =\n| image_size      =\n| birth_name      = Billy Edward Wheeler\n| alias           =\n| birth_date      = {{birth date |1932|12|09}}\n| birth_place     = [[Boone County, West Virginia]], U.S.\n| origin          = [[Whitesville, West Virginia]], U.S.\n| death_date      = {{death date and age|2024|9|16|1932|12|9}}\n| death_place     = [[Swannanoa, North Carolina]], U.S.\n| instrument      = Guitar\n| genre           = {{hlist|[[Folk music|Folk]]|[[Country music|country]]}}\n| occupation      = Singer-songwriter, playwright\n| years_active    = 1964\u20132012\n| label           = {{hlist|[[Kapp Records|Kapp]]|[[United Artists Records|United Artists]]|[[RCA Records|RCA]]|Radio Cinema|NSD}}\n| associated_acts =\n| website         = \n}}\n\n'''Billy Edward Wheeler'''<ref>[http://www.spencerleigh.demon.co.uk/Interview_Wheeler.htm Spencer Leigh interview] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080602145208/http://www.spencerleigh.demon.co.uk/Interview_Wheeler.htm |date=June 2, 2008 }}</ref> (December 9, 1932 \u2013 September 16, 2024) was an American songwriter, performer, writer, and visual artist.\n\nHis songs include \"[[Jackson (song)|Jackson]]\" ([[Grammy]] award winner for [[Johnny Cash]] and [[June Carter]]) \"[[The Reverend Mr. Black]]\", \"Desert Pete\", \"Ann\", \"[[High Flying Bird (song)|High Flyin' Bird]]\", \"The Coming of the Roads\", \"[[It's Midnight (song)|It\u2019s Midnight]]\", \"Ode to the Little Brown Shack Out Back\", \"Coal Tattoo\", \"Winter Sky\", and \"[[Coward of the County]]\" (which inspired a 1981 television movie of the same name) and have been performed by over 160 artists including [[Judy Collins]], [[Jefferson Airplane]], [[Bobby Darin]], [[Richie Havens]], [[The Kingston Trio]], [[Neil Young]], [[Kenny Rogers]], [[Hazel Dickens]], [[Florence and the Machine]], [[Kathy Mattea]], [[Nancy Sinatra]], and [[Elvis Presley]]. \"Jackson\" was also recorded by [[Joaquin Phoenix]] and [[Reese Witherspoon]] for the movie ''[[Walk the Line]]''. His song \"Sassafras\" was covered in the folk rock era by [[Modern Folk Quartet]] and [[The West Coast Pop Art Experimental Band]].\n\nWheeler was the author-composer of eight plays and musicals, a folk opera (''Song of the Cumberland Gap''), commissioned by the [[National Geographic Society]], and three outdoor dramas: the long-running ''Hatfields & McCoys'' at [[Beckley, West Virginia]], ''Young Abe Lincoln'' at [[Lincoln_State_Park#Lincoln_Amphitheatre|Lincoln Amphitheatre]], [[Lincoln City, Indiana]], and ''Johnny Appleseed'', at [[Mansfield, Ohio]]. He has authored six books of humor, four with [[Loyal Jones]] of [[Berea, Kentucky]]: ''Laughter in Appalachia'', ''Hometown Humor USA'', ''Curing the Cross-Eyed Mule'', and ''More Laughter in Appalachia'', and two as sole author: ''Outhouse Humor'', and ''Real Country Humor / Jokes from Country Music Personalities''. His first novel, ''Star of Appalachia'', was published in January 2004, and his second, co-written with [[Ewel Cornett]], ''Kudzu Covers Manhattan'', in 2005. ''Song of a Woods Colt'', a book of poetry, was published in 1969. ''Travis and Other Poems of the Swannanoa Valley (With Some Poems and Prayers by Dr. Henry W. Jensen)'' was published in 1977.  He was the featured author in ''Appalachian Heritage'' magazine's 2008 winter issue, which included 16 of his original paintings. [[North Carolina]]\u2019s ''[[Our State]]'' magazine featured him in its December 2007 issue. In 2018, Wheeler published a book of memoirs entitled ''Hotter Than A Pepper Sprout, a Hillybilly poet's journey from Appalachia to Yale to writing hits for Elvis, Johnny Cash & More''.\n\n==Biography==\nWheeler was born on December 9, 1932, in [[Boone County, West Virginia]]. He graduated from [[Warren Wilson College]] in 1953, and [[Berea College]] in 1955.<ref name=\"Allmusic\">{{cite web |last1=Manheim |first1=James |title=Billy Edd Wheeler: Biography |url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/billy-edd-wheeler-mn0000767622 |website=allmusic.com |access-date=December 19, 2019}}</ref> After serving as a student pilot in the Navy, he served as Alumni Director of Berea College. Wheeler recorded a couple of albums for [[Monitor Records (New York)|Monitor Records]], then from 1961 to 1962 he attended the [[Yale School of Drama]], majoring in playwriting.<ref name=\"Allmusic\"/> With Ewel Cornett, he co-wrote the musical ''Hatfields and McCoys'', which has been performed annually since 1970 by Theatre West Virginia in the Grandview Cliffside Amphitheatre (part of the [[New River Gorge National River]] area).<ref name=\"TWV\">{{cite web |title=Theatre West Virginia 2005 Program |url=http://www.theatrewestvirginia.com/files/program2005.pdf |publisher=Theatre West Virginia |access-date=December 19, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061119181326/http://www.theatrewestvirginia.com/files/program2005.pdf |archive-date=November 19, 2006 |url-status=dead}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Production History |url=http://theatrewestvirginia.com/production-history/ |publisher=Theatre West Virginia |access-date=December 19, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150511153315/http://theatrewestvirginia.com/production-history/ |archive-date=May 11, 2015 |url-status=dead}}</ref> He was married to the former Mary Mitchell Bannerman. They had two adult children, Lucy and Travis, and lived in [[Swannanoa, North Carolina]].<ref name=\"TWV\"/>\n\nIn the 1968 book by Milt Okun ''Something to Sing About: the personal choices of America's folk singers'',<ref>New York: Macmillan Company {{ISBN|978-0-02-592820-6}}; pp. 192-94</ref> Wheeler's choice was \"Turtle Dove\" (\"[[Fare Thee Well (song)|Fare Thee Well]]\"). He died at his home in [[Swannanoa, North Carolina]], on September 16, 2024, at the age of 91.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wtrf.com/west-virginia/west-virginia-native-songwriter-billy-edd-wheeler-dies-at-91/|title=West Virginia native, songwriter Billy Edd Wheeler dies at 91|website=Wtrf.com|date=September 17, 2024|access-date=September 21, 2024}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n! In June 2005, [[Country Music Television]] voted \"Jackson\" one of the 100 Greatest Duet Songs of Country Music.{{cn|date=September 2024}}\n\n==Bibliography==\n* ''Song of a Woods Colt'', Droke House (Anderson, SC) 1969\n* ''Travis & Other Poems of the Swannanoa Valley'', Wild Goose, Inc.\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n* [http://www.billyeddwheeler.com/ Billy Edd Wheeler], official web site\n* {{discogs artist|Billy Edd Wheeler}}\n* {{imdb name|2127675}}\n\n{{West Virginia Music Hall of Fame}}\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Wheeler, Billy Edd}}\n[[Category:1932 births]]\n[[Category:2024 deaths]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American male poets]]\n[[Category:20th-century American dramatists and playwrights]]\n[[Category:People from Boone County, West Virginia]]\n[[Category:Berea College alumni]]\n[[Category:American male dramatists and playwrights]]\n[[Category:20th-century American male writers]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from West Virginia]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Owen_Temple","to":"Owen Temple"}],"pages":{"6620213":{"pageid":6620213,"ns":0,"title":"Owen Temple","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n\n{{Infobox musical artist\n|name = Owen Temple\n|image =\n|caption =\n|background = solo_singer\n|birth_name =\n|alias =\n| birth_place  =\n| birth_date   = 1976\n|death_date =\n|origin = [[Kerrville, Texas|Kerrville]], Texas\n|instrument = [[Singing|Vocals]], [[Guitar]], [[Harmonica]]\n|genre = [[Folk music|Folk]], [[country music]]\n|label = El Paisano\n|associated_acts =\n| website = [http://www.owentemple.com www.owentemple.com]\n}}\n\n'''Owen Temple''' (born September 4, 1976 in [[Kerrville, Texas|Kerrville]], Texas) is an American [[Folk music|folk]] and [[country music]] songwriter and musician based in [[Austin, Texas|Austin]], Texas.\n\n== Career ==\nWork with producer and [[pedal steel guitar]] musician [[Lloyd Maines]] led to 1997's ''[[General Store (album)|General Store]]'' and 1999's ''[[Passing Through (Owen Temple album)|Passing Through]]''. The year 2002 saw the release of the [[Phil Madeira]]-produced ''[[Right Here and Now]].''\n\nIn 2007 and 2011, Temple was a [[Kerrville Folk Festival]] New Folk Finalist, and he was the winner of the 2007 [[B. W. Stevenson]] Songwriting Competition.\n\n''[[Two Thousand Miles]]'', a fourth studio project, was produced by Maines and was released on January 22, 2008 on El Paisano Records. A review in [[Allmusic]] noted \"great lyrics full of insight and plainspoken poetry.\"<ref>[{{AllMusic|class=album|id=r1268729|pure_url=yes}} ''Two Thousand Miles'' Allmusic, Poet, J.]</ref>\n\nA fifth studio album, ''[[Dollars and Dimes]]'', was released June 9, 2009.  It is a concept album focused on different regions of North America during hard times.<ref>[http://www.suntimes.com/lifestyles/hoekstra/1652006,TRA-News-Detours05.article] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090711140502/http://www.suntimes.com/lifestyles/hoekstra/1652006,TRA-News-Detours05.article |date=2009-07-11 }} Hoekstra, Dave (July 5, 2009). \"Playing off North America's regions, travel album delivers concept richly\". ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]''.</ref> In July 2009, the album was the No.&nbsp;1 record on the Euro Americana Chart.<ref>[http://www.euroamericanachart.nl/0709.html] for July 2009. Retrieved July 5, 2009.</ref>  In August 2009, the album was No.&nbsp;5 on the Freeform American Roots chart.<ref>[http://www.tcmnradio.com/far/far120.htm] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131126065540/http://www.tcmnradio.com/far/far120.htm |date=2013-11-26 }} for August 2009.  Retrieved August 10, 2009.</ref>\n\nA sixth studio album, ''[[Mountain Home (album)|Mountain Home]]'', was released April 26, 2011, and the songs on the album focus on small Texas towns and the eccentrics inhabiting them.<ref>[http://www.austinchronicle.com/music/2011-05-13/owen-temple-mountain-home/] Caliguiri, Jim (May 13, 2011). \"Texas Platters: Owen Temple - Mountain Home\" ''[[Austin Chronicle]]''.</ref>\n\n''[[Stories They Tell]]'', a seventh studio album, was released on September 24, 2013.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://jennifinlaypromotions.com/owentemple.htm |title=Owen Temple - Stories They Tell |access-date=2013-09-03 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131214193357/http://jennifinlaypromotions.com/owentemple.htm |archive-date=2013-12-14 |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n\nAn eighth studio album, ''[[Rings on a Tree]]'', was released September 29, 2023, and its songs, many co-written with Walt Wilkins, [[Hal Ketchum]], and others, comprise a concept album focused on intergenerational interactions. <ref>[http://www.rootshighway.it/outsiders/2023/temple.htm] Ricaldone, Remo (December 19, 2023). \"Reviews: Owen Temple - Rings on a Tree\" ''RootsHighway''.</ref><ref>[https://www.americanaboogie.com/americana-music-releases-for-sept-29th/] Frater, Bill (September 28, 2023). \"Americana Music Releases for Sept. 29th\" ''Americana Boogie''.</ref>\n\nA book on songwriting, co-authored with Gordy Quist, titled ''Songfarmer: Writing More and Better Songs'' was published on November 1, 2015.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://songfarmer.com/post/140510862321/songfarmer-writing-more-and-better-songs|title=Songfarmer: Writing More and Better Songs published by El Paisano Press |access-date=December 28, 2022}}</ref>\n\nDreamer: A Tribute to Kent Finlay, released in early 2016 on Austin-based Eight 30 Records, features Temple's version of Finlay's \"Mines of Terlingua.\"<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/dreamer-a-tribute-to-kent-finlay-mw0002916063 |title=Various Artists: Dreamer: A Tribute to Kent Finlay |work=AllMusic }}</ref>\n\n== Artist discography ==\n*''[[General Store (album)|General Store]]'' (1997)\n*''[[Passing Through (Owen Temple album)|Passing Through]]'' (1999)\n*''[[Right Here and Now]]'' (2002)\n*''[[Two Thousand Miles]]'' (2008)\n*''[[Dollars and Dimes]]'' (2009)\n*''[[Mountain Home (album)|Mountain Home]]'' (2011)\n*''[[Stories They Tell]]'' (2013)\n*''[[Rings on a Tree]]'' (2023)\n\n== Writer discography ==\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n!
